node	593	closed	12	bnoordhuis	2011-01-28 05:08:23	0.73		+1		b'b" Firefox 3.6.181. -1, -1000, NaN, +Infinity and -Infinity all make the callback run on the next tick.2. Values up to 2^31-1 schedule the callback in the future, 2^31 and up make it run on the next tick.3. Passing negative values to in node makes it throw an exception so in that respect we\'re not compliant."'
node	593	closed	13	bnoordhuis	2011-01-28 05:08:23	2.33		+1		b"b' @er88 Not immediately, at least not in 3.6.18. It runs on the next tick, a couple of milliseconds later.'

b'b\'  sporadically fails with "Cannot call method \\\'emit\\\' of undefined" error\''
b'b" This is observed with node 0.4.0 on cygwin.  I am calling  to connect to a server
column11: and sporadically am experiencing the following exception: :116    throw e; //  error
column12: or \'error\' event on first tick    ^I did some debugging and I believe that what is happening is that the server I am connecting to is sometimes not doing an orderly shutdown of the SSL conversation.  This is causing an ECONNABORTED error at my node client.  The catch is that the response has already been received and hence some cleanup of the node socket structure has already occurred within node
column13: leaving it with nothing to emit the error event to. At a code level
column14: take a look at .  The crash I am seeing is happening at line 1148
column15: where the code tries to emit the error event on the request object
column16: which is null.  It is null because
column17: prior to the error event being emitted on the socket
column18: the listener for the end event on the response (line 1244) was invoked
column19: which cleans up the socket (detachSocket at line 1256).  So the code as currently implemented is not expecting that an error event on the socket can be received after the full response has been received."'

column10: b'b" I also ran into this and would like to re-request it. I can understand the reasoning (thanks for providing it!)
column11: but it would be nice to have consistent behavior between the shell and files. Just a basic tenant of good software I guess -it shouldn\'t surprise you or behave in unexpected ways. Perhaps that means that modules in Node just should also be in their own context
column12: without the ability to mess with globals. That would eliminate some valuable use cases though
column13: like TJ\'s . So here\'s a strawman:1. Keep support for modifying globals. It can indeed be used for evil
column14: but it can also be used for good.2. Drop support for .clear by default in the shell; have the shell execute modules in the same context like files.3. Add a config or optional param to node to execute modules in a new context. This would apply to both the shell and files.4. Have .clear output a warning if called from a shell without that config or param. Thanks for your consideration!"'

column10: b'b" What if you create a  that loads the REPL. Doesn\'t work for testing?"'
b"b' In my opinion
column11: we should just make NODE_MODULE_CONTEXTS the default. Relying on shared access to the same global context is an antipattern that browsers foisted on us.  We have better tools now.'"

column10: b'b" That would cause other unintended effects
column11: consider: This evaluates true with NODE_MODULE_CONTEXTS=0
column12: and false with NODE_MODULE_CONTEXTS=1... Of course you can\'t be talking the same object if each of them have different methods. Exactly the effects that such isolation would have isn\'t quite intuitive:  require(\'./b\').arr instanceof Array; // false  (require(\'./b\')); // true  require(\'./b\') == String; // true  require(\'./b\').stringConstructor == String; // false"'

column14: but startup time. @isaacs "Relying on shared access to the same global context is an antipattern that browsers foisted on us. We have better tools now." I\\\'d disagree. (and
column15: what did you exactly mean by "better tools"?)Possibility to enhance existing classes is important part of dynamic languages from the time of Smalltalk. There it works
column16: and is often used
column17: and not so frowned upon
column18: technique (some of it
column19: like "isInteger" etc. in Object are due to architecture of the language
column20: in JS this would not be needed in Object
column21: but would be in Integer (that is
column22: Number
column23: here) anyway)
column24: In any case
column25: this makes true use of OO polymorphism. If you prohibit extending base classes (either by design as in Java and before
column26: or by convention
column27: you make the language lot less powerful
column28: I\\\'d say crippled. I would say what you blame the browsers is not their fault
column29: this is written entirely in the foundations of JS as a langauge it is mix of functional {heavy use of closures) and OO. This means
column30: you should be able to use polymorphism to its full extent inside the code you pass around in closures and this is the true point where you _need_ to be able to augment Object
column32: Array and String. It\\\'s true that some things can be done in pure "functional" way by calling the function on an object
column33: but there are lots of things that OO and its polymorphism is the right tool to use (and this may be really personal or philosophical
column34: but I was taught that polymorphism should be used heavily
column35: since it is clear way to solve "do this differently based on object type"
column36: which is far too common (lots of switch statements could be rewritten with good results for the readablity and maintainability to use polymorphism instead; not all
column37: of course)).Closures hold their lexical scope
column38: so they know their variables and functions; but they do not carry with themselves the OO bindings of their environment; that is I think the main cause of the problem when passed between contexts (and the multiple-root thing where instanceof Object fails).Sorta humorous is
column39: that this only holds for the base classes if you use your own classes
column40: defined in a module that is imported multiple times
column41: you can augment it and it happily works everywhere (since there is only one copy of it

column10: b'b\' To sum my subsequent lines of throught on this matter:1. Within the application
column11: there should be no contexts used for separating modules. Within one app
column12: every app classes are shared
column13: and so also Object
column14: Number etc. should be shared. The "context" is anyway more appropriate for an app
column15: not for every single module that it is built from.If you use contexts in your app
column16: you can
column17: but you have been warned.2. If there are more "apps" to be run
column18: they should be separated completely nothing shared. So not only should they be in different contexts
column19: but also modules they require should be different (of course
column20: so they use the actual Object
column21: etc.). This includes even the native modules.2a. One of the possibilities to separate apps is to launch child process.2b. Other possibility would be to allow to create a "jail" within node
column22: where not only new context is started
column23: but where the basics (native modules
column24: moduel system
column25: module cache
column26: etc.) are reinitialized for that jail. Then
column27: main script should run in such a jail
column28: repl should run in separate jail of its own (but within it
column29: everything\\\'s shared
column32: if it is just some sort of multiplexer
column33: should have possibility to create other jails to run separate applications within them.The "recompile for every jail" is not the performance problem a Script can be created and cached for each module in some sort of master cache
column34: then "compiling" the module in new jail in just the matter of running this procompiled Script in the context of the jail (this was my motivation for having unbound Scripts from the beginning)
column35: If you like the microkernel view
column36: this master cache can run as an app of its own
column37: in the jail of its own (some metacircularity that arises could surely be somehow solved).\''

column10: b'b" This whole thing seems like such a non-issue.  Repls are _very_ rarely perfect 1:1 replicas of the system they represent.  (Have you ever _really_ looked hard at the Webkit console or Firebug environments?  They\'re insane.)  Even bash is significantly different in interactive mode than it is from inside a script. Having to reset your session is really handy.  If you\'re really running into incompatibility issues in the repl
column11: then maybe that should be a sign that it\'s time to fire up your text editor.  Our repl is surprisingly polished and humane for such a young project."'

column10: b'b" It\'s the 24th field
column11: expressed in 4 kB chunks. There\'s an example in the other issue on how to parse it.That\'s a function of the garbage collector. When the heap is full
column12: the GC scans it in order to collect garbage and free up memory. To avoid too much scanning
column13: it will sometimes choose to grow the heap instead (and thus the RSS). That\'s business as usual and is in fact a good thing because it improves performance. If it makes you feel uncomfortable
column14: you can limit it with the flag."'

column11: but sometimes (not always) sudden death of a process can be prevent by adding \'error\' handler before opening socket. If there is no error handler
column12: nodejs process dies without recover
column13: but if a error handler is attached
column14: the error is caught by handler and could be handled safely. It could be applied to not only a socket connection
column15: but all kinds of network-related functions like TLS or HTTP."'

column10: b"b' issue:url '"
b'b" My feeling is that the assert(0) should not be there
column11: and that the comment querying where the request has gone is wrong: there are cases where the agent has a socket open
column12: but there are no requests in the queue.  In particular
column13: if a request was issued with keep-alive on
column14: but the request is now complete
column15: there will still be a socket object associated with the agent
column16: but no request.  In this case
column17: if the socket subsequently receives an error event
column18: node throws an error.  It arguably should do something to indicate that something unusual has happened to the socket (even though nothing really needs to knowthe actual request is long gone)
column19: but it should result in a much less dramatic error. I\'ve added a comment to url  linking to a pull request for a test case."'

column10: b'b\' I think I\\\'ve run into the same problem
column11: or else something very similar. When I attempt to pipe a readable file stream into a writable TLS stream (an http ClientRequest) the TLS stream write() eventually returns false
column12: causing pipe() to pause the file stream. It never emits a drain event
column13: so the file stream never resumes and the whole thing hangs. I have a simple demonstration here: url  If you change it to use http instead of https it will run to completion and print "SUCCESS"
column14: but with https it will hang.  I\\\'m running v0.4.8 on OS X.\''

column10: b'b" I think I tracked this down. When an HTTP client request is associated with a socket (either plain net or tls) it does not listen to the socket\'s \'drain\' event and re-emit as I\'d expected. Instead
column11: it relies on the socket to call its own ondrain() method as an optimization. See url  The problem was that normal net sockets know about this optimization and play along
column12: but TLS sockets do not. I\'ve brought TLS sockets up to speed and the test i posted earlier now passes.  This looks like a pretty clear-cut bug so I went ahead and put in a pull request. "'

column10: b"b'  partial character write is harmful'"
b'b\' Writing partial characters into a buffer results in the caller not knowing how much of a buffer contains complete characters
column11: without computing the character length of the string given to the buffer using: Instead
column12: simply do not write partial characters.  More precisely
column13: change the definition of bytes written to be bytes of complete characters written (as is the case for "utf8" encoding). Then
column14: one can optimistically write to a buffer with no loss of efficiency as follows:  \''

column10: b"b'  only commits complete characters. closing.'"
b'b\' 0.4.5 docs say:  "Writes string to the buffer at offset using the given encoding. Returns number of octets written. If buffer did not contain enough space to fit the entire string
column11: it will write a partial amount of the string. In the case of \\\'utf8\\\' encoding
column12: the method will not write partial characters." The last phrase implies that non-\\\'utf8\\\' encodings may write partial characters.\''

column11: stdout and unix pipelines'"

column10: b'b" The well accepted JavaScript idiom of writing adhoc diagnostic output with  and the current the decision by  to bind  to stdout creates systematic problems for anyone who wants to use  as a unix pipeline stage. The problem is that standard unix pipeline components reserve stdout for data and reserve stderr for all sideband information
column11: such as adhoc diagnostic information. The rationale for this practice is that it allows the consumer of a pipeline stage to trust that the stage is never going to write unstructured diagnostic output io stdout and thereby allows pipeline stages to be readily composed by connecting the output one to the input of another. As it stands
column12: one can\'t do this with  unless one knows that none of the modules that a  stage depends on use  for any kind of diagnostic output. In general
column13: one cannot know this and the answer may change over time. As such
column15: with its current implementation decision
column16: is unsuitable in general
column17: as a unix pipeline stage. This seems like  unnecessary restriction since it is otherwise well suited to such a purpose. I think  should change so that  is bound to stderr by default. If this is not possible because of concerns about backward compatibility
column18: then there should at least be an option on the  command line that allows stderr to be selected as the file descriptor to use for diagnostic output. "'

column10: b'b" Don\'t use modules that print to standard out it\'s no different in any other programming language. Closing."'

b"b' This is equivalent to the advice to:not use any module that uses the standard java script idiom of writing diagnostic output to stdoutto not use any module that you have not audited  for this ruleto not use any module that you do not control'"
b"b'   should be used to print to stderr.'"
b'b" I won\'t open the issue again
column11: but it seems you are missing the point. A standard JavaScript idiom is to use  for adhoc
column12: unstructured diagnostic output. I can choose to use () for diagnostic output myself
column13: but I can\'t control what the authors of arbitrary commonjs compliant modules do.  If these modules are used with nodejs
column14: then no guarantees can be made about the integrity of stdout generated by  modules and hence by nodejs pipeline stages in general. All the advice in the world from the author of  can\'t control how people choose to use an API
column16: in arbitrary  modules since that API and its idomatic usage isn\'t controlled by nodejs.  I will work on a solution that doesn\'t require your support to implement since I need a solution that allows nodejs to be reliably and safely used as unix pipeline stage irrespective of whether nodejs itself cares about supporting a long standing unix idiom."'

column10: b"b' Bug in exposing V8::Context as an Javascript object'"
b'b" Context is a special type of handle in V8 engine
column11: and is not accessible by javascript code.Node does make it accessible through CreateContext and EvalMachine. It\'s havily used by Node internally. But it seems there is a mistake at how Node does this job. Before running code in a sandboxed context it simply copies all first-level properties of the sandbox to the context. And it copies them backward after the execution is finished.Node correctly translates self-references (links to sandbox itself) but only at first level. **Deeply stored self-references are not translated**. And that\'s the core problem I think. It definetily is responsible for memory leaks like this one: url I tried to solve it by myself
column12: but failed. I\'m not an expert at Node and V8."'

column10: b'b" It\'s a bad idea to copy all the tree of object properties to translate deep self-references (if it\'s possible at all). So maybe there is some way to proxy access to javascript sandbox into context->Global() object in realtime?"'
b'b" \'Deeply stored self-references are not translated. And that\'s the core problem I think.\' That is not
column11: the problem is not gcing contexts (or
column12: its holder
column13: it is not published to js level directly). You can create other over-context loops using other external objects
column14: as well (for example
column15: to create tri-cycle with three sandboxes and three contexts; no translation will help you here). The problems is
column16: if it is
column17: in v8 not gcing over-context references involving external objects well.Maybe it was bad idea of runInContext\'s author (though
column18: it is elegant) to merge role of context and role of sandbox (they need not to be merged for a runInContext functionality)
column19: this may break the cycles. Maybe. But then
column20: two objects would need to be tracked (the context as well as its sandbox)
column21: because they shouldn\'t have references to each other. That would be cumbersome.context->Global() is very special object
column22: too
column23: so I don\'t know if it is possible to do anything useful with it (like injecting some proxying)."'

column10: b'b" It\'s a misbihaviour of Node. User gives a sandbox like this one: and the code running inside the context sees it as: That\'s very-very bad. We need help from core development team here."'
b'b" That\\\\s exactly the behaviour of it. It won\'t be fixed
column11: afaict. Shallow copying occurs. shallow translation occurs.Only thing you can get by this is that the translation would be removed completely (and cumbersome \'global = ({})();\' would need to be prepended before every script that need the self-reference). And once more
column12: there is no sane possibility that the translation can occur deeply. You are putting objects in the sandbox because you want _them_ to be used
column13: not their copies. And of course
column14: you don\'t want to change sandbox into context\\\\s global inside those external objects (which may in the meantime be used by other code asynchronously
column15: not to mention the need to restore it
column16: and what if the code inside changed them
column18: total mess). So what is exactly your point? Because this is _not_ very-very bad (every single object you pass into context\'s global through sandbox is external
column19: and every object such an object holds in its properties etc. down the tree. Every single one. Think about it for a while.). The non-gcing is very-very bad. Nothing else."'

column10: b'b\' When I say that it\\\'s very-very bad
column11: I mean that the user (developer) does not expect that the first-level properties will be translated
column12: and the next levels will not. That\\\'s not common sense. And I\\\'m sure there will be plenty of bugs in the future (and today) caused by this "feature".\''

column10: b'b" Nevertheless
column11: what is the _bug_? The title says about problematic exposing of v8::Context
column12: but you blame translating only first level (but only that is copied). These thing are orthogonal. Independent. So what is this issue really about?If you want to take away the translating
column13: you should (afaict) create new issue
column14: because memory leaks because of over-context cycles has nothing ever to do with the translating process
column15: but you always attack this process as the bad thing.And even if you manage to get the translation removed
column16: you won\'t solve3 anything
column17: because self-references may still appear. So
column18: what is it that _really_ bothers you?"'

column10: b'b" I think that the whole concept of how Node allows javascript code access contexts is bug-producing.Memory leak is caused by the same process: Notice that \'ctx\' is not a common object
column11: it\'s an object created internally by Node to hold the context data. And _that_ kind of loop references causes memory leak.I\'m not sure how that comes out
column12: suppose this is not a problem in V8 GC but in Node. BTW
column13: I found a hack how to fix it using .**proto** and one temporary field __box: No memory leaks
column14: no uncommon behaviour of sandbox.But it\'s a hack :) Probably it can be implemented inside Node itself?"'

column10: b'b" By the way: v8 globals are not in fact what they look like every global object in a context is in fact a proxy for the real global object. What you did with your **proto** magic is that you just disconnected the global proxy from the real global object and connected it to another object (the window). Despite the fact that this is a really bad thing to tamper with
column11: you in fact destroyed the whole concept of a context itself a context is a context because of its own
column12: different global with its private Object
column13: Number
column14: String etc. So in fact
column15: your code run in context of window
column16: not in context of what was ctx.I presume
column17: if you run your **proto** code many times and each time create new window object (not reusing an existing one)
column18: the leak may as well reappear (by that I am proposing the leak is still there
column19: but instead leaking the newly created context each time
column20: it leaks the (reused) window each time
column21: so you can\'t see it).Edit: But
column22: for the window-leak to be visible
column23: you should match the memory of the context with memory of the window
column24: so put a new Array(10000) into each such new window object)."'

column10: b'b" I did test as you proposed
column11: with new window containing Array(10000) no leaks. Yes
column12: you are right that code runs in context of window in my code. But this is one of two ways to run code in the environment fully determined by the developer. The other one is to create a _full_ copy of provided sandbox (with all self-references translated)
column13: and after execution copy all back. Is the way I did it dangerous? I don\'t have enough understanding of Node and V8 to see it."'

column10: b'b\' Thanx for running the test
column11: Strange that it did not leak... The contexts are more complex
column12: as I have written
column13: the context are about having all basic global object (Object
column14: String
column15: Number
column17: plus all their methods) private. If you want to use context to run in context of window
column18: you are really dangerously and error-prone abusing the mechanism of contexts
column19: which have the real global object and the actual global object decoupled through _ _ proto _ _ proxying which you hijacked. This can lead to very strange errors. Yes
column20: it can be labeled by the word \\\'dangerous\\\'. In any way
column21: there are two things the leak because of cycles involving WrappedContext and the rest (including the convenient "translation" mechanism)
column22: which are independent
column23: and the former is the problem
column24: not the latter. Since your _ _ proto _ _ manipulating code (which is not ES5-compliant
column25: so I look with some suspicion on it
column26: but it is there) stopped the leak
column27: it seemed the main source of leak is the (true) global object itself
column28: and the fact that _ _ proto _ _ manipulation is enough to stop the leak leads to (logical) conclusion that the \\\'this\\\' (that is
column29: context\\\'s global proxy) is the culprit that holds the leak came up
column30: that was my hypothesis from earlier post. This bring some more interesting questions as to where the leak\\\'s root is
column32: as I presented a few times before

b'b\' @gozala @fjacobs @ry  /cc @kriskowal I\\\'ve got an implementation in my "AMD" branch
column11: which provides compatibility with the other AMD implementations out there
column12: without getting into the underspecified semantics of the id and dependencies arguments.  Also
column13: it works with NODE_MODULE_CONTEXTS mode
column14: and passes all tests.  I still need to add some more tests and docs to explain and validate the behavior
column15: but in my cursory poking
column16: this seems to work pretty good and deliver what we want. Here are the relevant commits so far: url url  The goal of this should be to be _compatible_ with modules written for AMD systems
column17: while adding the minimum necessary API surface to node.  Towards that end
column18: I think that doing anything special with the id or deps arguments is misguided.  Only the last argument matters for node\\\'s purposes.  Since require() is synchronous anyway
column19: there is no advantage to pre-loading the dependencies.  (Clearly
column20: for systems that load modules asynchronously
column21: this is a much more relevant point.)\''

This way a new object  doesn\'t have to be allocated every time and the same hash object can be reused. Updating docs to reflect this change would be needed

column10: b'b" I certainly was not surprised by this behaviour and quickly came to the conclusion the crypto instances are not reusable. It\'s indeed explicitly stated in the documentation for both 0.4.x and 0.5.x...If it\'s not a security issue I suggest taking the advice of @dekz and making them reusable. I\'m not sure about cleaning up the crypto instance on a digest as this would add overhead to all existing crypto code. Here\'s two proposals...1. Reset on an after a  2. Expose a or method The latter of these options also better preserves backwards compatibility. That is
column11: any existing code which...presumes an after a will failrelies on some kind of final state of the crypto instance will continue to work since the new or method is not being called."'

column10: b'b" I\'m marking this as a feature request because it\'s a non-bug issue."'
b'b" Crypto instances are not reusable
column11: that\'s it."'

column10: b'b\' Fix module loading order of the file extension and add several test cases. In the case that the file extension is defined as number
column11: however it seems to be very rare
column12: its possible to fail the test while searching file extensions as in this request. This is because that () in V8 always returns number keys at first so that we must reorder the extension array to search module files in order of  ".js"
column13:
.node" and ".json"  url  Also, the description of rquire() of .json is added to the document.\''
node	1453	closed	1	shigeki	2011-08-04 08:49:10	351.22		+1		b"b' The  test (file14) of failure is a extremely paranoid case, so no one would set only number as a module extension. The current ECMAScript does not specify the order of elements returned by (). Although most of browsers now make it as the same order that the object properties created, we must not forget that V8 developers are free to change its behavior at anytime. I suggest that it would be better for us to remove such a peculiar implement dependency to avoid future troubles.'

column10: b'b" Why not just document that in the case where you have two files with load-able extensions
column11: and you don\'t specify an extension in the require() call
column12: then the precedence is undefined? -1.  This seems like it\'s solving a non-problem
column13: or at least
column14: an extremely rare problem."'

column12: and then .node."  into that of  "If the exact filename  is not found

column10: b"b' I think the above description is not intuitive for readers because people would not come across and understand the reason why the precedence breaks suddenly at that case. After trying some undefined cases
column11: they would find that the precedence still remains and believe that the description does not represent an actual behavior. Even if some developers know it comes from the behavior of  and ()  in JavaScript
column12: they would be surprised at  why Node dare not implement the explicit precedence of extensions to be good for all cases.'"

b"b' 100% CPU consumption by  native
column11: when ETIMEDOUT
column12: 110 code'"

column10: b'b" When node js creates a new connection to any port of remote host
column11: and the destination port has firewall configured to DROP it\'s packets or machine is down
column12: then  starts to consume whole cpu resource (top
column13: ps aux | grep node). After some system dependent timeout (something about 1 minute) system emits ETIMEDOUT to node net subsystem with error code 110. And after this occurs
column14: cpu consumption ends. The issue was tested with node-mongodb-native driver (module) which uses  to initialize its connection pool at startup. It sets 0 timeout on socket and nodelay option. It is not an issue when remote host is up and there is no listener on the port (no open port) and port is not under firewall
column15: or if the host is not exist on the net. Tested on Ubuntu Server 11.04 (default installation) EC2 micro.NodeJS v0.4.11"'

column10: b"b' Can you retest it with 0.4.12? That issue sounds suspiciously like one we fixed recently.'"
b"b' Yes
column11: i will test it.'"

column10: b"b' I have tested the issue updated to 0.4.12 and got the same results. Server seems to be responsive
column11: but cpu usage is 100% until etimedout returned on connect.'"

column10: b"b' Okay
column11: thanks. Do you think you can wrap this up in a test case? (Preferably without the node-mongodb-native dependency). I have an inkling of the cause but a reproducible test would help.'"

column10: b"b' While i was looking around for the test case of this
column11: i have found (with node debugger) that the issue is not a problem of  native code
column12: but it is of how mongodb driver manages it;s connection pool. It pushes one connection waiting method to the queue infinitely
column13: until some response from system got. And when connections just hungs
column14: this waiting method start to reiterate it self forever. I am sorry for bothering you. I was having very little time for digging the problem deeper. Best regards
column15: Ivan.'"

column10: b"b' No problem
column11: glad you found the cause.'"

column10: b"b' Hate to resurrect an old thread

column12: absolutely killing my production servers... and I have no idea how to fix it.'"

column12: and then manually copying everything that has changed back afterwards. It _sounds_ like we can rewrite that to utilize the passed context object _itself_ as the prototype for the
column13: and yank out all the ugly manual copying (also solving this bug); I\\xe2\\x80\\x99ll have to look into it more tomorrow.'"

column10: b'b" -1 to forcing customized prototyope to the global object.It\'s strange and I feel it dangerous."'
b"b' Short summary of the points I\\xe2\\x80\\x99ve considered
column11: considering exploring the global state of the from the outside. The old methodology of copying any values of the  \\xe2\\x80\\x99s globals back to the passed sandbox after the VM is finished is obviously inadequate. Copying causes all sorts of issues (such as those brought up by previous issue reports with depth-of-recursive-references
column13: nonproperties
column14: blahblahblahblah)
column15: and to boot
column16: it messes up whatever sandbox object you passed in (which is unacceptable if you intend to re-use it consistently as the same prototype of multiple  s\\xe2\\x80\\x99 globals.) Some alternatives include:Changing the API such that all of the run-methods return the globals (or v8 global-proxy) after execution has completed
column17: instead of the value of the last expressionProviding a separate API to acquire a reference to the globals (or global-proxy) for a given JavaScript-side
column18: as or similarDuplicating the old shallow-copy functionality
column19: but with a separate API as either of the last two describeProvide a global from within Node to all environments
column20: a l\\xc3\\xa1
column21: that can then be passed back out of the inner environment of a VM however the API consumer desires I\\xe2\\x80\\x99m not sure which of these (or something else entirely) is the most friendly / useful API. I\\xe2\\x80\\x99m open to suggestions as to where to continue from here.'"

column10: b"b' @herby any particular reasoning behind \\xe2\\x80\\x9cit\\xe2\\x80\\x99s dangerous?\\xe2\\x80\\x9d I\\xe2\\x80\\x99ve talked to the v8 guys
column11: there\\xe2\\x80\\x99s explicitly Nothing Wrong\\xe2\\x84\\xa2 with doing this. All of the magic happens with the prototype chain
column12: and you shouldn\\xe2\\x80\\x99t modify the prototype of if you value your skin \\xe2\\x80\\xa6 but there\\xe2\\x80\\x99s nothing unusual or wrong about setting the prototype of itself. As for the \\xe2\\x80\\x9cJavaScript\\xe2\\x80\\x9d-ness of it
column13: which I can see why you might be a little confused about \\xe2\\x80\\xa6 well
column14: it\\xe2\\x80\\x99s _exactly the same \\xe2\\x80\\x98hack\\xe2\\x80\\x99 that v8 itself uses_ to handle placing of the  -specific values into the \\xe2\\x80\\x9cglobal scope\\xe2\\x80\\x9d: their solution to the similar issue was the same as mine; \\xe2\\x80\\x9cuse prototypal inheritance on the object representing the top of the scope chain.\\xe2\\x80\\x9d If it\\xe2\\x80\\x99s good enough for

b"b' Need a way to detect ICMP errors with UDP.'"
b'b" I implemented SIP stack for node. SIP standard requires me to handle ICMP errors properly
column11: but it seems there is no way to detect  them in  v0.5.  AFAIK most UNIX systems report ICMP errors as errors in recvmsg syscall on _connected_ udp sockets only. Before v0.5 i was able to hack around dgram module and call (\'net\').connect on socket and got those error reports. On windows
column12: system reports icmp errors as error codes in WSARecvFrom
column13: and returns ICMP packet source address in lpFrom parameter
column14: but  doesn\'t pass it to user."'

column10: b'b" It was a conscious decision to not propagate network errors because Linux is the only supported UNIX flavour that reports them in a reasonable way. SunOS and the BSDs report ICMP errors only in connected mode which our sockets never are. I don\'t really want to add a special case hack to libuv just for this but I can see why it be useful to some. @piscisaureus: What do you think?"'
b"b' Why not just allow users to connect their udp sockets and handle network errors in portable way?'"
b'b" Since this is a design decision I\'m marking this a feature request while it\'s being considered."'
b"b' @bnoordhuis @piscisaureus Any update on this?'"
b'b" No. I think it\'s fair to say that (almost) no one cares."'
b'b" UDP sockets can be connected. I don\'t see a reason why node should not expose the system call for UDP sockets
column11: just map it 1:1 to ::connect(). It makes it easier to send packets
column12: makes it possible to filter junk out coming from unwanted addresses
column13: and last but not least it makes it possible to report ICMP packets. This is mandatory for SIP IPv6 compliance tests. No big deal IMHO."'

column11: having generated the project files with gyp. It is using llvm-gcc-4.2 and compiling for 64 bit instead of the default 32/64 bit. But I\'m sure it\'s more to do with the linker than compiler
column12: but Xcode is a bit opaque about exactly what it\'s linking to. We can\'t do a proper fix for gyp or waf until we know exactly what platform characteristic is causing it to pick up the version of the libraries with the x64-specific struct layout."'

column11: but maybe only on Lion also. The issue is that homebrew is using different toolchain settings from what  maintains and tests in waf and gyp. Until we know exactly what  and platform combination trigger the problem we could be making things worse
column12: not better. I think the  builds force ia32 so they don\'t suffer from the problem. That said
column13: it\'s really a toolchain problem; node should be free to use a system-provided struct definition stat without having to know the idiosyncrasies of which structure is used on which OS version and which processor

If homebrew is providing the toolchain configuration

column10: b'b" I spent a few hours at the weekend trying to create a standalone example of the problem but failed. The problem I originally fell over was reproducible  running any script
column11: even hello-. (Confusingly
column12: it would run REPL quite happily
column13: but a trivial script specified in the command line would cause it to fail.) The problem happens when node stats the script specified on the commandline. (node_) does a which allocates a
column14: including embedded stat struct
column15: on the stack. For some reason there is a mismatch between sizeof(struct stat) as seen by node_ and the platform\'s stat()
column16: because the call to the underlying stat() then writes beyond the bounds of the struct on the stack and overwrites the HandleScope that\'s just above it. Then
column17: on returning from Stat() or BuildStatsObject()
column18: the HandleScope::Close() goes wrong. I tried the combinations of compile flag from Greg\'s trace but couldn\'t get the problem to occur in a standalone test. I tried two compiler versions (i686-apple-darwin10 and i686-apple-darwin11) but I didn\'t reinstall all of Xcode so I probably don\'t have an identical environment to the others having the problem. What I know is that sizeof(stat) depends on whether you\'re building for x86_64 or ia32
column19: and in my case adding the D__DARWIN_64_BIT_INO_T flag resolved it;I assumed that it was compiling against the struct for ia32 but linking against the  library for x86-64. It seemed believable because
column20: if I was already building for x86_64 then adding the flag shouldn\'t have made any difference. However
column21: it\'s also possible that there was some other problem
column22: and adding the flag masked it just by making the struct bigger. What I also found out is that the flag also changes the size of the stat struct. We have this flag for some files and not others
column23: and you can definitely cause the same symptoms if node_ has that flag but the linker doesn\'t. But from Greg\'s log
column24: this didn\'t appear to be the problem. But there\'s definitely an issue here we can address going forward to have consistency in the compiler flags used across the different libraries. Finally
column25: I can\'t say for sure that these failures are all the same bug as I saw
column26: but if it\'s crashing in HandleScope and there\'s a Stat() call on the stack it certainly looks the same."'

column10: b'b" I grudgingly and reluctantly admit there may be a bug in how Node currently handles TTY and pipe I/O. In a nutshell
column11: a write request is queued for each call to  . The actual syscall succeeds immediately but the write request object isn\'t released until the next tick of the event loop which never comes in a busy loop."'

column10: b"b' Move npm files into %appdata% on windows 7 / vista'"
b'b\' After installing node using the .msi installer
column11: node is being installed into the "Program Files (x86)" folder
column12: where node does not have any permissions. Thus when using npm
column13: you cannot install global modules
column14: because node cannot write into the "Program Files (x86)\\\\nodejs\\\\node_modules" folder. Instead
column15: should store and look for npm modules somewhere in the user %appdata% folder.\''

column10: b'b" yeah
column11: %programfiles% is probably not the right place for node_modules
column12: also because it gets uninstalled when users upgrade to newer versions of node.  I do think that it\'s nice that installation of global modules requires elevated context."'

column10: b'b\' The npm_cache is already in the user\\\'s folder.  This is actually the more critical folder for npm.  If the intention is to share modules between users on the same computer
column11: then both npm_cache AND node_modules should be in Program Files. Personally I feel it is more "Windows 7-ish" to keep npm_cache in the user\\\'s folder
column12: and to put global node_modules in %appdata%. If you are creating a  app
column13: then you should install modules local to that app
column14: which will then run fine from any user that can access that app\\\'s directory.\''

column10: b'b" @piscisaureus Ok
column11: I\'m fine with it either way.  The tricky thing would be that %appdata%\\\\npm isn\'t in the %Path%
column12: so if you
column13: then you won\'t be able to run vows afterwards. Can we update the MSI to add %appdata%\\\\npm to the %Path% as well?"'

column10: b"b' Actually I am more for installing into the user folder. (Yes I know I change my opinion all the time. I should run for president.)'"
b'b" Now that we\'re at it
column11: npm-cache should not go into the user\'s root folder. Stuff it in %appdata%."'

column10: b'b" The question of where npm _defaults_ the cache and global prefix on windows for a manual install really should be an npm issue
column11: not a node issue. Nothing here makes me think that we should change where the msi-installed npm gets dropped
column12: especially since you probably _do_ want that updated if you update node. The problem I see with putting it in %appdata% is that the whole point of global installs is to install things that can be used from the command line.  If %appdata%\\\\npm isn\'t in the %Path%
column13: then it\'s not a good choice as a default
column14: but of course
column15: all that\'s configurable pretty easily. We could always have the MSI modify the %Path% to put %appdata%\\\\npm there
column16: in front of %ProgFiles%\\\\node."'

Only after manually granting write permissions for the nodejs folder to the current user npm ran successfully. Afaik by default you need elevated permissions (granted i.e. during the installation procedure) to write into the Program Files folder."'

column14: and will add things to the command line path
column15: but will not be requireable.2. will fetch a newer version of npm
column16: which will override the node-installed one
column17: so self-update will work.3. Installing a new version of node will install a new builtin version of npm.4. Manually dropping npm in the same folder as  will work as it does now
column18: so people who don\'t use the MSI don\'t have to do anything special. Does that meet everyone\'s needs?"'

column10: b"b' Reading this discussion and trying to figure out why installing in a user folder was ever thought of as the better choice... My use case is that another user (administrator also) is not be able to invoke globally installed modules installed by another administrator on the same machine (by default). That seems wrong to me. This also does not happen in the case of OSX
column11: as far as I know. url '"

column10: b"b' Windows At Install create a globally accessible folder as Admin
column11: this will be the global store and although it requires elevated privileges to create and assign permissions
column12: no admin is needed thereafter. In the simplest and least secure scenario this folder would simply be given  to everyone but if you wish to demarcate between reading and writing on the folder create local groups with differing permissions on folders and assign users to appropriate groups. In this case if the installation program asked where the folder should be created then with elevated privileges the folder was checked for suitablity  (if its not on an NTFS partition then none of this is relevant and the problem would not arrrise)
column13: the install would then either create and set permissions or just set permissions
column14: for the most users I suggest a default of (Admin: full control
column15: Authenticated Users: change) would be suitable. '"

column10: b'b\' In terms of real-world usage and requirements
column11: there\\\'s really three levels of installation global
column12: shared and local. For Linux and OSX a global install is globally available on the machine
column13: regardless of who\\\'s logged in (so it needs **sudo**). On Windows global really means "shared" which means global for the user and accessible outside of a repository
column14: but not globally on the machine (so no elevation is required). I\\\'m happy with the Windows behavior
column15: as most cases people use when they really want **shared** and not globally on the machine. I would argue that **npm** would benefit from having a third level of installation that requires **sudo** or **elevated** permissions for Windows (maybe keeping that as  ) and changing the current behavior of global now in Windows and call it  . This would make it consistent across platforms and the need to use less common for OSX and Linux users.\''

column10: b'b\' RSS is the resident set size.  That number never goes down unless there is memory pressure
column11: because libc doesn\\\'t actually de-allocate memory unless necessary when free() is called
column12: preferring instead to mark the pages as unused.  This greatly increases performance
column13: but has the unfortunate side effect of making RSS a bad indicator of memory usage
column14: since it will almost never shrink. What you should see in practice is that the RSS steadily climbs at first
column15: then levels off
column16: and only changes slightly.  Here\\\'s a test: url  And the results are 100% expected: url  RSS rises steadily
column17: until it hits the point where there is memory pressure
column18: then levels off. It\\\'s not accurate to say it "never goes down".  It never goes down until it has to
column19: because the memory is still tied to that process
column20: even though it\\\'s been freed.  If I watch the System Monitor on my mac while running this test
column21: the "Inactive Memory" sits at around 2GB
column22: which is almost the entire amount of RSS in use by the node process.  When the node process ends
column23:
Inactive Memory" drops down to 85.4MB. Since the node process was exerting memory pressure on the other processes, most of them gave up their inactive memory.  When the node process ends, the total inactive memory in use is thus very low. If you\\\'re looking at RSS to find memory leaks, then you need to watch for steep cliffs.  Steady climbs are expected, and healthy.\''
node	2328	closed	10	isaacs	2011-12-14 07:12:36	627.42	+1			b'b" 1 more point: The reason why a steep cliff would be bad is that it would indicate that the process was getting nuked by the operating system.  Of course, in this case, that would never happen.  You\'d just have your system get really sluggish as it paged out to disk."'

column10: b'b\' @vflash What you are seeing is normal behavior.  The vmstat utility shows that it\\\'s not paging to disk
column11: even when running for many minutes.  The RSS _does_ go down
column12: but only when it reaches the point where there is memory pressure.  Almost the entire amount of RSS is "unused memory"
column13: that is
column14: memory which has been free()\\\'d
column15: but not yet reclaimed by the system.  That is completely normal
column16: and expected. There are no memory leaks here.  You are misunderstanding what RSS is.  I\\\'m sorry
column17: I don\\\'t know how better to demonstrate it.\''

column10: b'b" feature request: allow process\' exit event handler to schedule future work"'
b'b" Adding an \'exit\' event handler to works well as a way to find out that node is about to exit
column11: but I don\'t understand why its handler cannot schedule new asynchronous events (for instance
column12: set a timeout) and thus keep Node alive.  It would be useful for me
column13: while unit testing
column14: to detect when the code under test has allowed the event loop to end. The only way I can do that is with a process exit handler
column15: but by then it is too late to do anything asynchronous
column16: so my test runner has no choice but to spit out an error and die. If it doesn\'t make sense to change the existing behavior
column17: would it be possible to have a new event that indicates Node event loop exhaustion? In this case Node would fire the new event first
column18: then only begin the exit sequence if the event loop is still empty."'

column10: b'b" We\'ve talked in the past about doing a which would fire when the event queue was empty
column11: but before it\'s torn down. @bnoordhuis @piscisaureus @koichik Thoughts on this?  I think it is still important to keep existing semantics the way that they are
column12: but we could add another actionable moment in the program lifecycle without breaking anything."'

column10: b'b" That\'s not quite the same problem. I know how many tests there are
column11: and I can obviously keep running until they are done. But this isn\'t just a loop; the tests are asynchronous and are expected to call a done() function when they complete. The trick is discovering when the code under test has failed in some way and neglected to call its callbacks. Unless I explicitly keep node alive by setting a timeout or something
column12: node exits and the best I can do is show an error. "'

column10: b"b' mocha is async as well (of course)
column11: but not invoking a callback is a user error
column12: so you can just timeout those tests'"

column10: b'b" Yes
column11: but then you have to wait for the timeout. If you could detect an empty event queue
column12: you could fail fast and get on with your tests
column13: but only if you could schedule new events. Right now you can fail fast but that\'s the end of your test run."'

column10: b'b" not really much of a big deal

column10: b'b\' im not saying it\\\'s a "bad" feature

column10: b'b" What you describe is exactly what I have done so far (see url  if you are interested)
column11: and it is a little less than the ideal I\'m seeking. Normally a timeout is used to halt a process that _may or may not_ take forever. If the event loop is exhausted then we know absolutely that it _will_ take forever
column12: so there is no reason to wait around for some arbitrary period to elapse. I think my ideal future scenario would be a test runner equipped with timeouts overseeing tests that run in separate isolates
column13: each one of which can detect its own event loop exhaustion and fail appropriately. That would be the best of both worlds: quick and unambiguous detection of event loop exhaustion combined with timing out of misbehaved tests (for instance
column14: code that calls setInterval and fails to clean up). I don\'t know if that\'s how isolates are going to work
column15: though
column16: so I may well stick with timeouts regardless."'

column10: b'b\' @visionmedia @csosborn I think there\\\'s a valid use case here

column12: make a bunch of requests to do stuff
column13: and then want to remove all the temp files whenever everything\\\'s done
column14: and it\\\'s just easier to do that all at once when you know it\\\'s over. Of course
column15: you can write your program so that your callbacks chain together and you know when it\\\'s all finished
column16: but this feature would possibly be easy to do
column17: and would make those types of programs easier.  People find it a bit odd that "exit" doesn\\\'t let you do any IO.\''

column10: b'b\' You are right
column11: my change breaks valid header values. I overlooked validity of CRLF as @koichik mentioned.I used regex
column12: that was a quick change and your comment is valid about performance. The issue I was trying to fix was related to http response splitting attack url  I was checking if this is possible in express and then noticed that it is
column13: via url parameter to redirect method
column14: which sets Location header with value url parameter passed in (if it is not mapped
column15: a nice feature in feature
column16: but this is also possible even url is generated indirectly). example : url response : url  When a header is set through setHeader function it is possible to add extra header  where value has CRLF (not part of LWS). I agree that applications that are using current behaviour may break if changed
column17: but I think current applications should be using this function as it is documented. As per documentation :So if an application is calling this setHeader and intentionally adding more than one header field by CRLFs that is not part of LWS
column18: then application is doing something wrong and better to be fixed. If they already use properly
column19: they should be fine. Also as per documentation setHeader function should not allow adding new headers or modifying other header fields unintentionally. At this point the solution that @koichik has proposed fits RFC and behaviour as per documentation. this example will set Location header as well: About http response splitting attack there are some good resources
column20: this page has nice content with examples and references: url  And in this blog different proof of concepts are presented for  (also mentions null byte in concept 3): url  If this check will not be done in core http library then I think it is better to mention in documentation
column21: because it is easy to overlook in library or application level.  At least for "Location" header
column22: I think it is better to fix

column13: we will be introducing a new string parameter into Stats which is way more expensive than a DWORD / uint32_t etc. On Windows we could combine dev + highIndex + lowIndex to reach whatever we need only when it\'s needed. Still lowerIndex serves the purpose (unless it\'s not ReFS) that ino is no longer 0.  I also would like to add that
column14: on Windows lowerIndex serves the file reference index purpose while the higher index is a sequence number and it changes only when i.e a new file is created etc. On NTFS file system these information is only reliable during a process life time (although I didn\'t see them changing
column15: it\'s highly possible the file system may reuse the index on a networked file system) thus we also shouldn\'t encourage people to store a string value that we created which may not be relevant when the process is restarted again in future. "'

column11: ino represents a sequence number which is mostly useless alone. However lowerIndex represents the file reference index which is most likely unique per app instance. My suggestion is that they could both hold lowerIndex etc. No it\'s not. BTW

column14: I wouldn\'t expect much performance issue since a system call would consume much more. However a smaller device that especially we are working on with JXcore would suffer from it.  If this statement refers to supporting ReFS
column15: I think we need much more than that and yet supporting it would require a small api break anyways.  Why bother instead of fixing what ino gives and sharing higher index from another property? I bet if there is any guarantee that a unix distro would always return a 32bit value for inode. It all depends to kernel and file system setup.  Definitely I\'m not an NTFS expert but wouldn\'t expect a dynamic index to server this purpose. I don\'t see much similarities among unix inode and Windows fileIndex apart from the unique id stuff. In details they both act different. I\'m agree with you that uid is the simplest option (but may not be the reliable one) yet I have other concerns. We are trying to keep node compatibility with JXcore while trying to figure out how to reduce the footprint. I would really appreciate if we use as less string as possible on the critical parts of the library. I\'ve just wanted to share an option that we don\'t need a string.  Besides
column16: my experience with Windows 10 ARM (iot)
column17: I\'m having a hard time to believe that dynamic file index is something reliable. Maybe it\'s just a preview edition problem but who knows. No hard feelings :) We are just discussing to do the best. "'

column10: b'b\' This turns out to be one of those problems that seem simple at first... here is what happens in the failing cluster:1. Master starts worker.2. Worker requests socket from master.3. Master creates a new socket and tries to bind it.4. The syscall fails but that error is not immediately reported by libuv.5. Master sends the unbound socket to the worker.6. Worker now has a useless socket. The reason that libuv does not immediately report the error is that it tries to mimic an OS X "feature" where EADDRINUSE isn\\\'t reported until a later syscall. Being consistent across platforms is a great idea but in this case it actively works against us. One solution is to make either the master or the worker check that the socket is really bound. The question is: who should do it and what happens next?\''

b'b" One of the main purposes for is that a worker process (lets call it  ) should be allowed to run without a master (not using any cluster). For that pure purpose the error should be emitted in the worker like any normal error. My first thought on a solution would be to change (this is executed form a worker when using cluster)
column11: to check that the port isn\'t used (as you suggest).  However thinking more about this that solution would fail
column12: since : So a better solution would be: This is slightly more complex
column13: but it will work and require less I/O. The complexity is:the result will have to be savedif more workers request a handler before the port is used they will have to wait until until a decision is made. I will try making a fix to in today or tomorrow if you have no objections."'

column10: b"b' It returns the renegotiation count so far. Since Node uses OpenSSL in non-blocking mode (i.e. Node spoon-feeds the network data into OpenSSL as it comes in) we can easily keep track of the count and warn or abort if it exceeds a threshold.'"
b"b' Lighttpd 1.4.30 uses to count the number of times occurs.  Checkout [network.c]url  Once the connection is accepted
column11: is set back to 0.  As far as preventing client-side regotiations... checkout the [connections.c file]url  Hope this helps!'"

column10: b'b\' @ssuda As of openssl 0.9.8l
column11: renegotiation was disabled completely
column12: although it was re-enabled in 0.9.8m.  From what I can tell
column13: this is definitely a problem in 0.9.8r.  Again
column14: this is not a "security flaw
column15:
it is more of a DoS vulnerability.  I can confirm this problem in OpenSSL 1.0.0e. As @bnoordhuis mentioned, disabling renegotiation completely will generally prevent most clients from authenticating with client authentication.  While you can do client authentication without renegotiation, most HTTPS implementations use renegotiation (server-initiated, I believe) to request the client certificate.  However, I don\\\'t think client-initiated renegotiation is needed to do client authentication... only server-initiated renegotiation.  So, I think disabling client-initiated renegotiation completely is a viable solution. Finally, you can\\\'t just set an option (SSL_CTX_set_options came to mind) within OpenSSL library; it must be written into the Node library.  Please checkout the Lighttpd code above.\''

column10: b"b' No Error for Malformed Groups in Regex in REPL'"
b'b\' When the REPL tries to execute a regex which contains a malformed group
column11: it prints the same "..." it would usually print when the input contains a syntax error or is incomplete in itself. e.g.
column12: This is less a problem when entering it directly in the same line
column13: but it becomes a greater issue when the regex in question is in a called function
column14: which could be in an included module
column15: and runs counter to the usual meaning of "..."
column16: which is that immediate input is syntactically incomplete. Instead it would be much more helpful if it printed an actual error (and stacktrace)
column17: something along the lines of what a browser might print
column18: such as the following error message from Chrome:  \''

column10: b'b" The problem is likely that while both are syntax errors
column11: a JS syntax error will manifest in a failure during the compile phase while a regex syntax error will compile and fail during execution. A syntax error in JS will throw during where a regex syntax error won\'t."'

column10: b'b" @Benvie: Not quite. V8 reports it as a SyntaxError. However
column11: this bug is probably not fixable in the REPL. The REPL evaluates the current line after each keystroke in a VM context until it sees a valid expression (i.e. until it doesn\'t throw a SyntaxError). That approach works reasonably well but it\'s easily fooled: try entering
column12: for example."'

b'b" I have put some more thought in this. The event is first called when using  . So if we implement this so will ask all slaves about how many only connections they have and then begin counting down to 0  . And then emit when is zero. This is different from just using the IPC to tell the parent when connections are closed
column11: because there isn\'t a need for using IPC while the slave is on heavy loaded. And usually you don\'t care much about speed after calling  . The is still an issue

column10: b"b' HTTP parse error on request using a non standard method'"

b'b" I\'m trying to serve PURGE request from a HTTP server implemented using . PURGE requests are used by Squid and Varnish to purge objects from their cache (cf. url  and url  But \'s HTTP server does let not my code serve non-standard HTTP method. Instead
column11: when receiving a request line using a non-standard method
column12: the server close the connection after a parser error. Server code and output: Client command: According to the HTTP 1.1 specification (rfc2616
column13: section 5.1)
column14: the method of a request line can be any valid token
column15: so it seems natural to expect an HTTP server to accept any method in the request line and answer with an error 501 (Not Implemented)."'

column10: b"b' This seems to be a  of http_parser and has been reported there (cf. url '"
b"b' Reopening this for now
column11: -parser#93 adds PURGE support to http_parser.c but it needs updated bindings in node_http_. EDIT: Updated in @9986989.'"

column10: b'b" Hi @bnoordhuis while that does solve the immediate problem
column11: what\'s your take on the generic issue at hand allowing any non-standard HTTP method? I agree with @pbuyle that at least a 501 response should be sent on non-supported methods
column12: while it would be better either to support any non-standard method to be parsed or to allow the set of methods recognized by the parser to be configured at runtime."'

column10: b'b" It\'s been discussed a couple of times but nothing really came of it. I would accept a patch that doesn\'t impose a speed or memory penalty."'
b"b' PURGE support landed in f0c5165 and de5e3f6. Thanks for the report.'"

column13: go ahead if you want to have a stab at it."'

column10: b'b" To clear up any misunderstandings
column11: what happens here is that DNS lookups and async file I/O share the same thread pool in C land. Said thread pool has limited concurrency so if DNS lookups are slow because the nameserver is down (to name something)
column12: that also slows down file ops. It\'s a  issue."'

column10: b"b' This is a very serious issue
column11: as queuing only 4 DNS queries will delay everything else using the thread pool. Considering that a DNS query can take more than 20 seconds with default  settings
column12: if the thread pool queue is filled with DNS queries
column13: everything can be delayed for minutes or even hours.'"

column10: b"b' Are there any blockers to Node using  internally for  etc? And leaving  for those that need it?'"

b'b" I\'ve responded to your question on the mailing list.  For posterity:tl;dr () and friends won\'t be switching to () anytime soon. The scalability of the thread pool is a subject of ongoing research; it\'s possible to speed up specific workloads by a factor of 10 but not
column11: it seems
column12: without regressing other workloads by a factor of 5 or more.  That won\'t do
column13: of course. If you want  to use more threads
column14: run before starting node."'

column12: it could accept any of these:

This might be unacceptable in time-sensitive applications (i.e. reading from a hardware device such as a serial port).4.) and friends read when Node starts to determine which nameservers to use. column12: it will remove that from the supplied hashtag.### Example: Both the href and the hash keys have a malformed value.### Expected:  ### Version:  "'

column10: b'b" That\'s because quotes (single or double) are not allowed in URLs
column11: they need to be URL-encoded."'

column10: b'b" If we look at how browser handle this you can see they are much more forgiving about this
column11: and don\'t care if it\'s URL-encoded or not. And this is a much more desired behavior than node is currently doing. "'

column10: b"b' I agree with @3rd-Eden on this one. @isaacs ?'"
b'b\' The issue here is that quotes are in the "delims" set
column11: as per RFC 2396.  I\\\'m not opposed to moving them to the autoEscape set
column12: though
column13: since our intent is to follow the browsers as the de facto standard.  I\\\'ll fix it.\''

column10: b'b" Note: we still **won\'t** support or several other characters that are accepted in  ."'
b'b" Hm
column11: this brings up very interesting questions. What about the case of  .  Should that parse as or or even: (since isn\'t valid in a protocol or in a host
column12: so clearly is part of the pathname.) And what about obviously malicious stuff like  ?  Currently
column13: that parses as: which is nice and safe. If we change this to be identical to web browsers
column14: then that\'ll be: I\'m not saying no to this
column15: necessarily.  But it does require revisiting a lot of other edge cases that so far
column16: we\'ve been able to just punt on
column17: and reduces the utility of our url parser in data sanitization scenarios."'

column10: b'b" Allowing unescaped quotes doesn\'t strike me as a good idea. Liberal handling of quotes made possible at least [one browser exploit]url "'
b'b" @bnoordhuis Well
column11: no
column12: _leaving_ unescaped quotes in the URL is not on the table here.  We\'d auto-escape them to %22. The simplest approach here is just to treat the same was as we treat today
column13: by auto-escaping rather than delimiting on it.  But then what about space
column14: or  ?  That\'s what I\'m curious about.  At what point is this a data validator
column15: as well as a replacement for the url bar."'

column10: b"b' Fixed in master.'"
b"b' Remove offset check when creating a typed array view of a Buffer'"
b'b" A check in the TypedArray constructor in makes it impossible to create a view of a Buffer with an offset that is not a multiple of the array\'s property. Because of this
column11: to create a view of the Buffer
column12: the second constructor argument ( ) must be a multiple of 4
column13: or the constructor call will throw an error. I may have overlooked some fundamental reason as to why this check is necessary (the [spec draft]url  doesn\'t mention one). The way I see it
column14: it only causes unnecessary pain when
column15: for example
column16: serializing a typed array from a stream. I also took the liberty of rewriting the tests for typed arrays ( ). The old version incorrectly used instead of
column17: meaning it practically couldn\'t fail."'

column10: b'b" It\'s because unaligned accesses are not allowed on some architectures
column11: have strange semantics (look up what ARM does) or because it\'s slower (from 2x slower to literally 1000s of times slower). I want to thank you for taking the time to write this PR but you\'ll understand that I won\'t take it. :-)"'

column10: b'b" @bnoordhuis The point about chunks coming in odd shapes is good
column11: though
column12: and it\'s a bit annoying to force the user to slice just to get the right alignment. Can\'t our Uint32Array method just do the slice instead?"'

column10: b'b" Perhaps I\'m about to open a huge can of worms
column11: but if we have to worry about unaligned access then wouldn\'t we have to check the adress of the buffer\'s underlying memory block as well? That isn\'t currently being done
column12: and the issue with that becomes apparent when you realize that we can slice any portion of a buffer. Both Uint16Array instantiations will succeed
column13: but one of them has to be unaligned. Unfortunately I can only think of three ways of sorting this out
column14: none of which are very appealing:1. Only read individual bytes from the buffer\'s memory block
column15: then combine them to larger types in the software layer. This would of course bring with it a performance penalty
column16: and would have to be maintained separately from v8\'s typed arrays.2. Completely remove support for creating typed array views on top of buffers.3. Check whether the buffer\'s memory block is aligned with the type of array we\'re going to create
column17: and throw an error if it isn\'t. This would of course lead to very unpredictable errors in user code."'

column10: b'b" I don\'t see how that could work. The slice is a view of the buffer
column11: not a copy. If you\'re suggesting to do two loads and assemble the result
column12: read on.Indeed. It\'s not an option.It\'s a feature that got added by popular demand so that\'s not a viable option either.That seems like the only sensible approach."'

column10: b'b" Ok
column11: I\'m convinced.  Thanks
column12: @bnoordhuis and @mjor."'

column10: b"b' Response object for HTTP '"
b"b' I started a thread on nodejs-dev about this
column11: but it looks like my posts are still in the moderator queue. Will link it here once it gets through. Briefly:The first commit is a test showing that a pipelined Upgrade request to a Node server can cause an out-of-order response. This is because the handler gets immediate access to the socket
column12: while other requests may still be processing async.The second commit fixes this by providing a response object even for Upgrade
column13: that is also queued properly along with other responses.In addition to fixing the test
column14: I find it makes sense to have a response here. Per the spec
column15: CONNECT and Upgrade **must** be followed by a proper response
column16: before handover. Regarding
column17: I have one failing test both before and after this patch set
column18: namely  . I consider this a platform irk. plain crashes the test suite on (also before and after)
column19: but a fair amount of HTTP tests do pass.'"

column10: b'b" @npcode The issue was not that unlinkSync doesn\'t work. The problem is that on windows
column11: when you unlink a file that is opened
column12: it doesn\'t really get deleted. It is just marked for deletion
column13: but the directory entry is still there until the file is closed. That\'s why rmdirSync would fail. I fixed it by making readFile close the fd before making the callback."'

column10: b'b\' I figured it out guys. It turns out your example gist is basically misusing node-weak by defining the weak callback function in the same scope as the object being monitored. It\\\'s actually rather strange
column11: but by creating a persistent reference to the callback function
column12: it for some reason thinks that the function will access
column13: even though it doesn\\\'t. This _could_ be a V8 bug
column14: but I\\\'m going to modify the node-weak readme to recommend a "best practice" for defining callback functions. The fixed version is here: url  Closed :)\''

column10: b'b" Ok
column11: as this affects only
column12: the callbacks do not have to be changed
column13: even if I add more advanced callbacks for \'data\' and \'end\'?"'

column10: b'b\' @nicokaiser This "only define the callback outside the scope" rule only applies to node-weak because it stores a persistent reference to the given callback function until the object is GC\\\'d. This causes a crazy cyclic dependency and therefore the object can never be GC\\\'d. Other callbacks like "data" and "end" don\\\'t have that persistent reference that node-weak creates and thus will get GC\\\'d properly
column11: so defining them inline (anonymously) is perfectly fine.\''

column10: b"b' This has come up several times.  The answer is no.  is intended to be used to run a copy of node.  It is quite easy to write a JavaScript program that loads coffee-script
column11: and then uses that to load your coffee-script program
column12: or to compile your program to JS before running it. However
column13: in v0.8
column14: you will be able to specify an arbitrary stdio file descriptor as and then do the messaging stuff with it
column15: and even send handles across it
column16: so the need to do this with the sugar method will be greatly reduced.'"

b'b" I couldn\'t really understand [this commit message]url  _(Make () even faster)_
column11: as there was some crappy code in the module. So I tried to make it a true statement (not just for that function
column12: but for the whole module)
column13: optimizing at different places. Some of the things that were optimized:**Avoid switch statements**: At one place
column14: there was a switch statement that just checked for a single condition. Extremely wasteful. Besides
column15: if-else constructs are much more readable.**Don\'t cache typeof**: A couple of days ago
column16: I found [this test]url  at jsPerf
column17: which is pretty interesting. It looks like V8 optimizes calls
column18: so caching the call is actually bad. I created a [fork]url  including the switch statement

b'b\' 1. I disagree that the code is "crappy".  It\\\'s not clear that a switch statement is "wasteful".  Making the claim that it is requires justifying that with a node benchmark.2. Any changes for the purpose of increasing performance are not acceptable without benchmark numbers proving that they are in fact an increase in performance.  (Pull requests for the chnages in 5e3ca981556c305830553d006b76d5dcaaf49276 and 5166758927e7538d413b030d3b586107cd53024d were accompanied by benchmarks showing speed improvements.)3. Benchmarks must be done in node
column11: not in JSPerf
column12: which tests _browser_ performance.4. Unless you can show that\\\'s it\\\'s actually a significant chunk of the time spent in a real workload
column13: it\\\'s not worth the change.  (Again
column14: the other optimizations in this area were in response to actual detected bottlenecks.)\''

column10: b'b" @isaacs:1. A switch statement that has a single condition + a is wasteful. Not (only?) in terms of speed
column11: but in terms of space (when a single would have been enough).2. Okay
column12: fair point. The main bottlenecks I found were the following:At [L144]url  and are called multiple times with the same data. I think it\'s obvious that caching that value speeds things up (by some factor).Besides
column13: a new array is created in [L208]url  most of the time with the same content. The total impact is pretty hard to show in a benchmark
column14: as garbage collection is pretty important in this case. A check for the length of the array would fix that. I changed more than these two things
column15: but they are the essence. 3.As long as you are using only APIs that are included in V8 (which is the case for this pull request)
column16: it shouldn\'t matter where a benchmark is run. (I\'m open for any benchmark showing the opposite ;-).) 4.I figured that for a performance critical module like every bit of performance matters. Therefore
column17: I also included optimizations that don\'t impact speed in a way that everyday users will notice. Now I see that I should have left them out
column18: as their main impact is the size of this pull request."'

column10: b'b" Please remove the changes that replace the switches with .  You may find them more pleasing

column14: especially when those cosmetic changes introduce lint failures."'

b"b' A common code pattern I see in projects that need to attach to another is this: The problem is that 78dc13fbf97e2e3003e6f3baacdd5ff60e8de3f7 causes removeAllListeners to maintain the array reference returned by the listeners call
column11: which results in new side effects: since Node v0.7
column12: the listeners array shown above will be updated with new event listeners attached. In Node v0.6
column13: the call to listeners() acted like a copy
column14: so this code would not result in a loop. If the listeners array is copied before being used
column15: the v0.6-style behavior can be obtained. For exmaple
column16: see: url  This is currently a problem for the [dnode]url  project
column17: which uses  0.8.6 that uses this pattern for handling HTTP upgrades. This was also a problem with my own code as well. For the sake of easy upgrades from v0.6
column18: I request  for the existing behavior to be maintained. If this request is denied
column19: the wiki about 6-to-8 changes should be updated to reflect this behavior change: url '"

column10: b'b\' I\\\'m generally in agreement with @reid on this.  We advertised that the behavior of require(\\\'events\\\') wouldn\\\'t change
column11: and here it is clearly changed.  It is clear that a compromise will not work: either the listener array is a persistent reference after removeAllListeners
column12: or it is not.  It\\\'s easy for @reid (and others) to work around in their currently-existing-in-reality programs
column13: but they shouldn\\\'t have to; it\\\'ll be even easier to work around the other direction in programs that don\\\'t yet exist. That being said
column14: what\\\'s the actual harm caused by not leaving the array intact?  So far
column15: the main arguments for not reverting are (a) "the docs say so"
column16: and (b) "oh
column17: it\\\'d be cool if you could...".  For (a) we can change the docs
column18: and for (b) we can shrug and say "Sorry
column19: that\\\'s not how it works
column20: do a different thing". But not to be too hasty
column21: are there other arguments for keeping the new behavior?\''

b'b" The object is a bit weird.  It doesn\'t do prototypical inheritance at all
column11: though its member evaluates to an object.  What\'s worse
column12: it reports errors in these cases **really** strangely: The historical reason for this is that  is actually a proxy object that calls getenv and setenv behind the scenes.  This is important
column13: because it provides a way to interact with addons that may be running in the same process (but not in the V8 runtime.)  If they call then the results should be visible on this object. However
column14: the EnvSetter and EnvGetter functions should treat differently
column15: and should use the  as the prototype
column16: so that  behaves more like a regular JavaScript object. Also
column17: whatever is causing that in the TypeError has got to go.  It should report its value as or some such. This cannot be done in Node v0.8
column18: since it is a behavior change."'
