b'b" allow \'sys\' to be an alias for \'util\'"'
b'b\' In the migration of Joyent\\\'s extensive node-based software stack to 0.8
column11: we have found one of the most tedious (and enraging) issues to be the removal of \\\'sys\\\' for \\\'util\\\'.  Yes
column12: we know that this has been deprecated for quite some time -but it doesn\\\'t change the fact that \\\'sys\\\' has worked and that making this change was excruciatingly painful. (No
column13: we didn\\\'t decide to assign \\\'sys\\\' to the results of "require(\\\'util\\\')" -and if that were the recommendation
column14: wouldn\\\'t that undermine the putative rationale for the removal of \\\'sys\\\'?)  To quantify the effect:  we had to make thousands of changes across tens of repos -changes that were exasperating
column15: to say the least (with great opportunity for a slip-up that wouldn\\\'t manifest itself until
column16: say
column17: a critical error message resulted in an uncaught exception).  History has taught us that the issues that we at Joyent experience are likely to be experienced by the broader node base; for this reason
column18: we believe that \\\'sys\\\' should be permitted as an alias for \\\'util\\\' for the indefinite future.\''

Yeah, but that\\\'s what you said about sys, and that still works." So, either way, we suffer a reduction in credibility with respect to a specific sort of message.  Which message do you think we\\\'ll be saying more of in the future?1. "Please upgrade to this new version, it\\\'ll be better, I promise."2. "Please don\\\'t use this feature, it will be removed." Unless someone can point to a real hazard of making it not throw, this doesn\\\'t even seem debatable, really.  The arguments against this proposal are basically, "But that\\\'s not what we do". node	3577	closed	18	bcantrill	2012-06-28 16:57:46	0.27		+1		b'b" When you innovate in systems software, you will make changes that break people.  The challenge is to restrict those changes to those which are absolutely necessary -where supporting the old way of doing things is truly constraining for future development.  This is not an example of that; supporting \'sys\' as an alias for \'util\' has no real cost going forward.  And to Isaac\'s point:  breaking it _does_ have a cost.  That cost is both immediate (changes need to be made), but the deeper cost is the erosion of trust:  if node breaks apps for capricious reasons, you will find a reluctance to upgrade and adopt -and ultimately you will find significant portions of the community disaffected and yearning for an alternative.  Part of maturing as a platform is accepting that this trust is important, and violating only when you absolutely must."'

The message of @shtylman and others in this thread is not un-heard, though.  We need to clarify our policies.  I don\\\'t want node to turn into PHP, either, and we\\\'re certainly not going to un-make breaking changes every time it upsets someone.\''

b'b" Emit \'close\' on destroy()
column11: so that pipe is cleaned up"'

column10: b'b" This patch emits \'close\' when you call destroy on a zlib stream. For pipe to end properly
column11: needs to eventually emit \'close\' once. This is necessary is order to properly clean up any pipes that come off the stream.pipe\'s event listeners will be cleaned up
column12: and the call to destroy() will be propagated down the piped streams
column13: by calling  . If close is not emitted
column14: the rest of the stream will be expecting another call to or but it will never come."'

column10: b"b' Guess the connections in the TIME_WAIT state could be the problem?'"
b"b' @bnoordhuis ?'"

b'b" When building TCP client server systems it\'s easy to make simple mistakes which can severely limit scalability. One of these mistakes is failing to take into account the TIME_WAIT state. In this blog post I\'ll explain why TIME_WAIT exists
column11: the problems that it can case
column12: how you can work around it
column13: and when you shouldn\'t.TIME_WAIT is an often misunderstood state in the TCP state transition diagram. It\'s a state that some sockets can enter and remain in for a relatively long length of time
column14: if you have enough socket\'s in TIME_WAIT then your ability to create new socket connections may be affected and this can affect the scalability of your client server system. There is often some misunderstanding about how and why a socket ends up in TIME_WAIT in the first place
column15: there shouldn\'t be
column16: it\'s not magical. As can be seen from the TCP state transition diagram below
column17: TIME_WAIT is the final state that TCP clients usually end up in. url "'

column10: b"b' TIME_WAITAfter the connection was closed the socket enters the TIME_WAIT state. In this state it can live for 60 seconds by default. This time can be changed with sysctl (in milliseconds divided by 2. 2\\xc3\\x9730000 MSL = 60 seconds): sysctl =30000  portsOutgoing connection are bind to the ports from the 49152 \\xe2\\x80\\x93 65535 range (16 thousands). It is better to be increased (1024 \\xe2\\x80\\x93 65535): sysctl =1024sysctl =65535 To use ports in natural order instead of random (to make the second connection for the same port impossible before TIME_WAIT): sysctl =0 In FreeBSD 6.2 the possibility to not create TIME_WAIT state for localhost connections was added: sysctl '"
b'b" Here is my configuration changes
column11: if you\'re interested. ~% cat / sysctl =16384sysctl =1024sysctl =0sysctl =1sysctl =7500sysctl =16384sysctl =204800sysctl =200000"'

column10: b'b" I see you\'ve figured it out already. Consider this an affirmative nod. :-) By the way
column11: turning off is not necessarily a good idea unless you\'re on some really ancient kernel that has trouble allocating ports in a truly random fashion."'

column10: b'b" Yes.What are you going to do? If there are no ports available
column11: there are no ports available. That\'s just how TCP stacks on every major OS work."'

column10: b"b' If you retry it works'"
b'b" Yeah

It would probably be better to test for at the beginning of the function.I added a test file and tried to follow the style of other test files. Don\'t know if this is what you expect
column11: or if I put it in the right place (this is my first pull request). Thanks @tchambard for spotting the problem."'

column10: b'b" I don\'t think this is a good change. The rule of thumb in node is to emit an error event or pass an error object to the callback when it\'s a run-time error (e.g. network outage
column11: disk full
column12: etc.) but throw on programmer errors. Passing in a bad encoding name falls squarely in the latter category. This PR would make sense if encodings were pluggable but that\'s not the case now
column13: the list of supported encodings is static."'

column10: b"b' You are assuming that the encoding is hard coded in the source. What if it was read from a database table
column11: or from a message header? IMO APIs should be more robust that that. They should not crash the entire process because a parameter has an invalid value. It is ok to throw if the programmer passes a null where a non-null value is required but not if a code is not in a list of allowed values (which may be static but may get more valid values in the future).'"

column10: b'b" Then you didn\'t sanitize your inputs properly."'
b"b' How do I check that the encoding is valid. Is there an API that returns the list of valid values? If not
column11: I have to hard code the list. What if node is enhanced to support more encodings?'"

node	3918	closed	6	bjouhier	2012-08-24 11:48:30	642.47	+1			b'b" @weiribao  This would be horrible. The code would fail a bit further down the line and the developer would have no clue why result is undefined. @bnoordhuis  I\'ve been thinking more about it. Your philosophy is to distinguish between run-time errors and programmer errors, and to only propagate the run-time errors through the callback, and let programmer errors crash everything. This does not match the _programming by contract_ methodology url  that I have been using for years and that works really well in our domain.  Would be better for us to have node report _all_ exceptions through the callback. But this would probably mean a lot of changes in the core JS code. I thought that this encoding issue was an isolated glitch but it is not. It is deliberate and consistent with your EH philosophy. So I won\'t be pushing this further. This won\'t be hurting us much anyway. We can still use our methodology because all our async code is written with streamline (so we can handle our own programming errors with ). We just have to be aware of this when writing low-level I/O code that interacts with core or 3rd party modules. Nothing too serious as this code is well isolated and rather small. And BTW, we did not run into the problem because of some kind of bogus input. We found it when unit testing our exception handling code. We deliberately passed to :-) Closing it. "'

We are using the exception handling methodology that goes with it (and which is well explained in B Meyer\\\'s OOSC book) but we are not loading our code with tons of useless assertions. Our contracts are usually _implicit_.\''

column10: b"b' On 32-bit
column11: overly constrained system heap induces std::bad_alloc exception'"

column10: b'b" As part of what appears to be address space layout randomization
column11: V8 allocates its heap by randomly mmap\'ing pages. This is done via the hint to mmap (that is
column12: by specifying an address but without MAP_FIXED); if the address is not available (because V8 has already mmap\'d part of its heap there)
column13: mmap will find an available address.  The range that V8 selects for its random hints is from 0x2000000 to 0x60000000
column14: and any sufficiently long-lived node process is therefore likely to mmap() part of the V8 heap at or near 0x20000000.  The problem is that the break (that is
column15: the system heap) grows from the bottom of the address space -and a mapping at 0x20000000 will prevent the break from moving past it.  This
column16: in turn
column17: causes malloc() to fail (inducing std::bad_alloc exception) after a mere 512MB -which is less than 10
column18: 000 64K Buffers.  Here\'s simple code which demonstrates the problem: On 0.6
column19: the above runs without incident; on 0.8 it dies: To fix this -or at least improve it significantly -the range from which V8 randomly selects hints should be moved much higher:  to 0x80000000 or more."'

b"b' The patch looks reasonable but it will break with kernels that are compiled with a 2 split. Are you going to send it upstream? EDIT: I take that back. On Linux
column11: V8 uses MAP_FIXED in a couple places but it first does a mmap() without (i.e. addr is only a hint)
column12: and then it does a second mmap() call with MAP_FIXED set. It seems this patch is safe.'"

column10: b'b" I see this behaviour on linux
column11: but not on windows. It is probably an artefact of how glibc handles large heap (de)allocations. @bnoordhuis
column12: thoughts? @tereska I doubt that this is actually the cause of your memory blowing up. Even if freed memory isn\'t returned to the OS
column13: it can be re-used for later buffer allocations. So if node ends up using all your server\'s memory
column14: you probably allocated so many buffers _at the same time_ at some point. PS: it\'s generally considered helpful to post a test case (check)
column15: the product version (?) and your operating system (?) to bug reports. Now we\'re left guessing."'

b"b' Hi
column11: In this example
column12: when I increase  url  for 800 kb
column13: so now it has: Memory is properly released to the system. What about this? Tested on node v0.8.14
column14: debian 6.0.6

column10: b'b\' Your test case is valid for certain values of \\\'valid\\\' but the behavior you\\\'re seeing is not a bug
column11: it\\\'s an artifact of how the malloc() implementation in glibc works. What is happening is that the allocated memory is not returned to the system. The \\\'why?\\\' needs some explaining... There are two ways for a program to request memory from the operating system
column12: mmap() and brk(). mmap() claims a slab of memory somewhere in the address space of the process that can later be released to the operating system again. brk() is different. It sets the "break"
column13: the address where the process "ends"
column14: initially address (code + data + bss). If you want to allocate 256 bytes
column15: you call brk(current_brk + 256) and claim the memory between the old and the new break as your own. glibc sometimes uses mmap()
column16: sometimes brk() it depends on a number of things. Allocation size is one of them. The issue with brk() is that while in theory it\\\'s possible to release memory again
column17: in practice that never happens and
column18: AFAIK
column19: glibc doesn\\\'t even try. If you trace your test case with
column20: you\\\'ll see numbers comparable to this: In other words
column21: nearly all allocations are done with brk() and they don\\\'t get returned to the OS. When you increased
column22: you made glibc use mmap() instead. I\\\'m not going to change the default pool size in  though
column23: because that strategy is unreliable at best. :-) For example
column24: it doesn\\\'t affect the  ratio with 64 bits builds. Hope that clears it up for you.\''

column10: b'b" @bnoordhuis  Although definitely a defensible stance
column11: we could consider to actually call mmap (maybe optionally) when allocating a buffer. Lately we have seen a lot of bug reports reporting this problem. IMO this is a shortcoming of glibc if your program allocates a lot of memory at some point in its lifetime
column12: it will never be reclaimed; the unused memory may get paged out at some point
column13: but that is essentially a waste of swap space and (hard drive) time. Also note that this problem does not exist on windows or darwin. On Darwin brk() is only available for backward compatibility reasons
column14: but libc never uses it. It is not even possible to move the break beyond 4MB. On Windows
column15: brk() doesn\'t exist
column16: and (by default) the heap is essentially managed by the OS."'

column10: b'b" I guess that\'s an option. I\'ll reopen the issue for now."'
b'b" Tentative patch here: @82bc42a Performance-wise it\'s mostly a wash.  is 1-2% faster with 8k buffers
column11: mmap is 0.5-1.0% faster with 32k buffers. That\'s with the micro-benchmarks in \\\\* that allocate myriads of buffers in a tight loop. Note that you need to run node with expose-gc and patch the test case to call gc() from time to time to see the effects. On my system
column12: RSS drops from 220M to 16-20M after a sweep."'

column10: b"b' @bnoordhuis maybe we could create an argument which could be passed to node binary or an environment variable using which we could decide how big FastBuffer we want at startup?'"
b'b" It\'s not about FastBuffers
column11: it\'s about the size of the SlowBuffer that regular buffers are split off from. Frankly
column12: the initial SlowBuffer could be 1M. Who cares? Who\'d notice?"'

column10: b'b\' I think the issue here is that we\\\'re mistaking intended system behavior for a "leak"
column11: because RSS is a very poor indicator of program memory _usage_.  Perl has had this in their FAQ for many years: url  There are occasionally actual C/C++ memory leaks (and JS reference leaks) in Node.  But increasing RSS due to brk() calls is not a problem we ought to solve.  We trade too much performance for not very much memory usage gain.  Users who know that they will be creating a lot of small buffers can increase the
column12: or we can probably come up with a heuristic to dynamically enlarge it if it would be beneficial.  But forcing mmap for every allocation is far too costly.\''

column10: b'b" Another strategy would be to re-use the memory allocated for SlowBuffer objects when they are reclaimed
column11: rather than letting the OS take care of it.  Of course
column12: that introduces some added complexity
column13: and the potential for _actual_ memory leaks. What would be ideal is if the OS could make this all Just Work
column14: by letting us re-use memory that was ostensibly freed for subsequent allocs.  (I\'m talking with the SmartOS people at Joyent about some other solutions for this.)"'

column10: b'b" Reverted for now in 6c5356b
column11: re-roll in 8dc9dca. It\'s interesting that using mmap() with the StreamWrap slab allocator causes a performance drop. It makes sense in a way; allocating large chunks is slower than allocating small chunks."'

column10: b"b' @bnoordhuis do you consider using alternative to glibc allocator? maybe jemalloc url '"
b'b" @soymo I\'ve experimented with jemalloc in the past but it was consistently slower than glibc\'s malloc by about 2% in our benchmarks. As to why
column11: I don\'t know I didn\'t dive in too deeply."'

column10: b'b" I\'ve decided not to land the mmap patch. I ran extensive benchmarks on both quiescent and loaded systems. Using mmap()
column11: even when finely tuned
column12: is as often harmful as it\'s beneficial. The interaction with the regular slab allocator is also quite intricate to say the least. The one place where it really seems to help is on systems with intense VM pressure; carefully pre-faulting the pages reduces the number of page faults by often ridiculous numbers (from e.g. 400
column14: 000/s). But we optimize for the common case and it\'s decidedly unclear if this patch is always a win. Ergo
column15: WONTFIX."'

column10: b'b" This is fallout from a change in Webkit.  It used to be that Webkit had only 2-byte (UTF-16
column11: more or less) strings.  V8 had ASCII strings (that can be converted to UTF-8 with memcpy) and 2-byte strings.  The 2-byte strings sometimes had shared storage with Webkit strings (external strings in V8 usage). Now WebKit has support for 1-byte Latin1 strings.  See url This means that if V8 wants to share storage with WebKit
column12: which it does
column13: it has to support Latin1 strings too.  It\'s too painful for V8 to support 3 different kinds of strings (2-byte
column14: Latin1 and ASCII)
column15: so ASCII support was dropped.  Unfortunately the Latin1->UTF-8 transformation is not nearly as simple as the ASCII->UTF-8 transformation
column16: and this is an issue for node."'

column10: b'b" Imagine you\'re on a postal office and giving heavy letters to the worker. He\'ll stay and keep all your letters until he\'ll be able to go to the storage. If you\'ll give him all letters at once
column11: he\'ll hold very big amount of data (1.5 gb). But if you\'ll wait for him to come to the storage and return back to you
column12: before giving him the next letter worker won\'t need to hold everything at once and will use much less data."'

column10: b'b" That\'s a very narrow view of how APIs are used. You are assuming it is called with static arguments that can and should be fixed during development. Otherwise
column11: you are expecting the API called to duplicate the input validation effort which is wasteful. Also
column12: combining input errors with execution errors has value in helping produce 100% test coverage in the JS code. For example
column13: I don\'t know how to test the past of my code that deals with randomBytes errors via a callback because I can never make it happen. On the other hand
column14: the sync flavor is easy to test. In this case
column15: I just gave up and switched to use the sync version which made me sad (but solved my test coverage and ugly code issues). The bottom line is
column16: some errors are returned via a callback and some are thrown. This makes for a messy interface. You seems to be assuming that the API user has checked the C++ code to see what errors can be received via each channel. The effort in passing ALL errors via the callback is trivial. Unless there is an architecture value in the current design
column17: it is just broken. I\'m happy to do all the work of going through every single API and fixing this
column18: but was unable to figure out how to return the above error via the API. If you can provide one example for the randomBytes code
column19: I will do a PR for everything else... So I\'m willing to put my money where my mouth is. This is not just me complaining..."'

column10: b'b" I\'m assuming that you check your inputs before passing them on
column11: yes. If you feel that\'s redundant
column12: I don\'t know what to tell you.There is value and it\'s not broken. Application bugs should be punished
column13: swiftly and at the call site. Passing on the error to the callback a) makes debugging harder
column14: and b) convolutes bugs with runtime errors."'

column10: b'b" You are missing the point. We all write code that takes inputs from somewhere else and calls node APIs. Those APIs already do the heavy lifting of input validation. No need to do it twice. The point is only how these errors are delivered. In a callback architecture
column11: it is much better to return all errors in a consistent manner which is through the first error argument of the callback. The fact that some errors are thrown and some are returned via the callback means that the application code has to handle both cases which leads to: ugly
column12: unreadable code and to the fact that now callbacks are returned within a  scope that has no business handling potential callback throws... The only practical implication of this is that some people will write ugly code that deals with every error scenario
column13: and others will just assume it doesn\'t throw and ignore it. That\'s bad design. The sync version of these functions return all errors via an exception. Nice and clean."'

column10: b'b" I do not agree with @bnoordhuis on this.  We need to have consistency in how we report errors to the user.  Programs are typically made of many interconnected parts
column11: and throwing from an async function is very surprising
column12: because now you have to catch errors in two places. We had this same discussion regarding bytes in fs functions.  Here\'s the pattern we established there:1. Async  Bindings: assert() and abort() to kill the program if the internal API is used incorrectly.  (Users should _never_ see this happen
column13: indicates a bug in node.)"'

column10: b"b' If someone can point me to an existing place were a validation error is returned via the callback in C++
column11: I am happy to submit a PR and even review other places for the same pattern.'"

column10: b'b\' This is an issue that will require more discussion with the broader community. There are clear "doing it wrong" application errors.  Consider something like  .  Node can know at the start of the function that this is clearly wrong. Should we throw there
column11: because you passed in bad arguments?  Or pass the error to the callback? One approach says
column12:
Application errors and run-time errors are fundamentally different.  In the first, the programmer is doing something that is clearly wrong, and the best way to debug it would be to crash asap.  In the second, the  is in an unexpected state, and the best way to handle that is to use the normal mechanisms (passing the error to the callback).  Deferring detectable application errors violates the principle of raising errors as soon as possible, and loses information about the call site." The other says, "We already have an error-handling mechanism for async functions: the callback.  The cost of having two mechanisms for raising errors (in additional code cruft and program instability) is not worth the value of having errors reported sooner, even if they are detectable.  When multiple parts are connected, the difference between \\\'application error\\\' and \\\'run-tme error\\\' is much more vague, especially in a weakly typed language.  Throwing from async functions violates the principle of least surprise." Clearly, regardless of which approach wins out, it must be documented and clearly explained which functions can throw, what situations they will throw in, etc. There are vocal people on both sides of this debate.  Both have good points, and clearly want what\\\'s best for Node.  The question is: which is the vocal minority? We\\\'re not going to change this for v0.8.  I\\\'ll write up a doc page about error handling to cover how things work there, and we can use that as a jumping off point for perhaps changing the policy.\''

column10: b'b\' Jumping in a little late here
column11: but feel a little adamant about this one. (as it sounds many are =) It seems to me that throwing on bad programmer input is the fundamental way js works
column12: and honestly shouldn\\\'t even need to be mentioned in the documentation (though if the documentation doesn\\\'t state exactly what the input should be
column13: then it needs to be fixed). Since js doesn\\\'t care how many or what arguments you pass
column14: often they\\\'ll need to be parsed anyways so the function knows what to do. Then if the wrong arguments are passed it\\\'ll leave the function in an undefined state. @hueniverse there are problematic assumptions you\\\'re making in your examples. First is that you assume ease of writing is more important than easily identifying bugs while using the api
column15: and that it wouldn\\\'t be easier to debug. The first example
column16: with corrections to your incomplete sanitizations
column17: is going to be far easier to debug since it fails the moment I try to use it improperly. And the point of throwing is not to improve test coverage
column18: it\\\'s to smite you for using it improperly. The second is that you assume a callback was actually passed. So if it\\\'s not
column19: and you try to call it
column20: the application will throw regardless. Also for some reason you still felt the need to wrap the call in a try catch. If you\\\'ve properly sanitized your inputs this should not be necessary
column21: and if it is then they\\\'re not being sanitized properly. As both you and @isaacs have pointed out consistency is key
column22: and I completely agree. Where I disagree is in the definition of "consistent". I\\\'ve pointed out one scenario where the async call must throw from bad input. So making an exception for that case breaks consistency.\''

column10: b'b" @trevnorris First
column11: node is not JS. Or at least this has nothing to do with JS and everything to do with the node API. I agree that we can\'t make an absolute rule about callback vs. throwing because the callback itself can be the problem. But that\'s also an obvious edge case exception. My preference is to pass ALL errors via the callback **whenever possible**. This leaves the \'bad callback\' error as the only one throwing (or when the API code itself is broken). I think the cost of returning errors via a callback is insignificant on the API side vs the overhead of catching alongside a callback on the client. My examples are meant as a strawman. The point is that to make them identify all the possible issues (which you consider the better way to catch bugs at the expense of developer ease and readability)
column12: I had to read the API source code in C++. That cannot possibly be a requirement or even a suggestion. Expecting the documentation to identify every possible error that can be thrown or returned isn\'t practical either. The API code keeps changing
column13: along with new errors and error conditions. You can\'t possibly expect developers to read the C++ or internal modules JS code diff on every release to replicate those checks. And without full replication of all the tests for error conditions that throw
column14: I still must use a . And then of course there is the sin of repeating the exact same validation code twice (or more with nested calls). A quality API checks inputs for you
column15: not forces you to check everything ahead only to be repeated. But I\'m in no way an absolutist and think there is an easy
column16: **pragmatic middle ground**. After all
column17: making the changes I am asking for will take some effort and time
column18: and so this can be viewed as a step. The key here is how we define \'coding error\' vs \'runtime error\'. I think we can easily agree on: Application errors:Bad data typesIncorrect number of arguments Runtime errors:Out of memoryHardware issuesNetwork errors Which leaves out what this thread was originally about:Bad input (with the right data type) One view is that this is an application error because it\'s predictable and can be tested for and prevented. Another is that most function inputs are generated at runtime in a working system
column19: and represent a valid error situation. From a purely pragmatic perspective
column20: it\'s safer and more efficient to treat bad input as a runtime error. The API call is going to validate the input anyway (if it doesn\'t
column21: it will throw and that\'s a bug in the API code) no need to duplicate effort on the calling side. Bad input errors are much easier to handle in the callback because it usually means notifying someone else about it. If we treated bad input as runtime error
column22: it will address 99% of my concerns. I can live with true application errors throwing and will not need to  them. One last note when I say bad input **with the right data type** I mean the right JS data type
column23: not C++. This means that if I pass a number
column24: but the number must be a C++ uint32
column25: that\'s a runtime error
column26: not an application error. We cannot require developers to manually check the boundaries of their numbers on every call (along with reading the C++ code to understand those boundaries). Expecting a number and returning a callback with bad range error is the right approach."'

b"b' Uint8Array(uint8arrayInstance) does not copy.'"
b'b" I ran into a bug in cifre when running node
column11: where creating a new Uint8Array from another caused the new instance to share the same backing store as the original.  In the browser this does not happen unless you explicitly pass in the underlying ArrayBuffer of the original into the second\'s constructor.  "'

column10: b'b" Here is the workaround I\'ve done for now in cifre: url "'
b'b" From the spec:So it\'s up to the implementation to decide how this is done."'
b'b" @trevnorris is technically correct the best kind of correct but it\'s probably best to follow browser behavior here. Principle of least surprise and all that."'
b"b' Can someone review @94d2ad0?'"
b"b' Fixed
column11: for better or worse

column10: b'b" FWIW
column11: I think the browser behavior that node will soon match is better.  In practice there are many times I want to share the backing store and many times I want a copy.  Being able to choose by either using a Uint8Array or it\'s ArrayBuffer makes working with these things easier."'

column10: b"b' @bnoordhuis forgot to implement the same with DataViews:  '"
b"b' DataViews [are meant]url  to\\xc2\\xa0be interfaces
column11: not\\xc2\\xa0copies.'"

column10: b'b" @Mithgol I realize that
column11: but take into account:So technically DataView\'s shouldn\'t be able to read in a TypedArray. Only an ArrayBuffer. There\'s a footnote that states:But since node allows for it
column12: think it\'s in the best interest that DataViews follow the TypedArray specification."'

column10: b'b" Okay
column11: fixed in 7b0770b. I guess it\'s technically a violation of the spec but we\'re not supposed to accept anything besides ArrayBuffers in the DataView constructor anyway. I\'m reopening the issue because there\'s still a bug that needs to be addressed: the .buffer property on the  object points to the original
column12: not the copy."'

column10: b"b' Original fixes reverted in fd9d8b5 and 144e21e
column11: proper fixes landed in 234551a and fe10335. Note that the DataView constructor now follows the spec (and the browsers) and no longer accepts typed arrays or buffers.'"

column10: b"b' @bnoordhuis Allowing typed arrays and data views to accept buffers is a nicety that was added pre-v0.8. See GH-4257. Think that specific change will need to be reverted.'"
b'b" For the future reference
column11: that\'s how you have just broken my #26 simplification of the [DataView]url  module."'

column10: b"b' Typed arrays still accept buffers. The reason the DataView constructor no longer does is that it creates some subtle semantic Ergo
column11: allowing buffers was a mistake and one that should be rectified sooner rather than later.'"

column10: b'b" And before someone brings it up
column11: yes
column12: you could make a Buffer object look like an ArrayBuffer by giving it a byteLength property but that doesn\'t make it one. For starters
column13: the slice() method works different."'

column10: b"b' @bnoordhuis please update Buffer documentation that states Buffers can be used with DataViews.'"
b"b' Yes
column11: yes. Done in 30b0bc4.'"

column10: b"b' Windows-only memory leak when writing to slow clients over sockets'"
b"b' While working on a streaming media server in
column11: I noticed a memory leak that affects Windows  hosts only.  Linux hosts are not affected.  (I did not test OS X.)  I am using the official binaries
column12: 0.8.19 on both systems. For my server
column13: I have a buffer of data (~1MB) that is sent when new clients connect
column14: and then I send live data behind it as new data comes from the encoder.  I noticed that clients often use the TCP window size to rate limit the data coming from the server.  VLC in particular will accept about 256KB of data
column15: and then close the window until it has more room in its buffer as the media plays.  Because of this
column16: about a 768KB buffer remains in the socket buffer on the server to be sent to the client.  768KB because the initial size written to the socket was 1MB
column17: and data beyond this initial buffer is being encoded at the same rate of playback.  This is not the problem
column18: and is expected behavior. The problem comes in with Windows.  It seems that since the  never reaches 0
column19: it continuously climbs until the server runs out of memory.  That is
column20: while I am continuously writing to the socket and the client is continuously reading
column21: the heap memory usage grows at the rate additional data is being written to the socket.  I have done a significant amount of testing and packet sniffing to confirm that the data is reaching the client at the expected rate
column22: but even though data has been sent from the front of the socket buffer
column23: it still occupies memory.  Again
column24: the code works great and as expected on Linux.  This issue appears to be Windows only. I have worked up a small code example.## ##  The server sends a 1MB buffer upon connect
column25: and continues to send 32KB of data every second.  It logs the socket bufferSize to the console every second.  The client attempts to rate limit data it receives to 32KB per second by  the stream as necessary.  On Windows
column26: you will see the bufferSize grow indefinitely.  On Linux
column27: it will be maintained below 1MB. I apologize for the crudeness of this example... but I think it should illustrate the point.  Please let me know if additional clarification  testing is needed.'"

column10: b"b' Observations in v0.9.10-pre (1ba39226b2235a6cad40c10d802cffc1f7cdf23d built from src on Windows). If I change the server log line: bufferSize grows
column11: writeQueueSize stays at 32768
column12: and _ grows.  Growth for bufferSize and _ stops around 1MB.'"

column10: b"b' Thanks for the bug report. I can confirm that Linux and OS X appear unaffected. Linux: OS X: Eventually writeQueueSize settles at 32K and _ oscillates between 190K and 420K. /cc @isaacs @piscisaureus'"
b"b' I apologize
column11: there was an error in my comment regarding the latest code in v0.9.10-pre.  It seems like this problem does not occur with my test code in this version.  I am unable to test a real-world example at this time as my application crashes in v0.9
column12: but the test example does seem to work in Windows with v0.9.10-pre. Are you accepting bug reports for v0.8 that are not bugs in v0.9?  If not
column13: this issue can be closed.  '"

column10: b'b" @piscisaureus or @sblom
column11: maybe you can look at this? I can\'t reproduce it with v0.8 on the Unices."'

column10: b'b" @bnoordhuis The problem doesn\'t occur on *nix.  It only occurs on Windows.  To clarify:  The problem on Windows is that the  grows indefinitely.  On *nix
column11: the  only grows to the point at which I have written data that could not be sent to the client yet
column12: due to the window size.  The problem does not occur on v0.9.10-pre on Windows.  If v0.8.19 on Windows will not be patched
column13: then this issue can be closed and I will wait for the stable release of v0.10."'

column10: b'b" I don\'t think so. If you call
column11: you will want to know that the data has been received."'

column10: b'b" From TCP
column11: you care about ECONNRESET (as @bnoordhuis said
column12: if you sent data
column13: you\'d want to know that the data actually got there)
column14: but from the node API that is really annoying.  But with the example above the likelihood for either errors emitted when nobody is listening  memory leaks because listeners get left attached after the socket is dead seems high. I\'m not super familiar with the new streams yet
column15: but I assume is really just (or the equivalent thereof)?  If so I would think you want to eat the error IFF the socket has _really_ ended
column16: that is
column17: if it happens during anytime before our end sends a FIN
column18: then emit error.  If it happens after the FIN
column19: then meh
column20: we should be able to safely drop it.  Thoughts?"'

column10: b'b\' So
column11: it seems
column12: there are three times when an ECONNRESET can occur:1. allowHalfOpen stream
column13: any time 2. writable side ending (but not finished) 3. writable side fully ended It\\\'d be quite easy to write a patch to make it happen this way in
column14: and I think tls streams just proxy the raised error events. Just to make sure we\\\'re not losing information
column15: I\\\'d suggest that the "not an error" case still raise a "reset" event or something.\''

column10: b"b' Sounds good.'"
b'b" Apparently those cases are already handled like EOFs anyway.  Re-closing.  If someone can show a failing test where node handles ECONNRESET improperly in v0.10
column11: then they\'re cleverer than I am
column12: and we can fix it then :)"'

column10: b'b" Reproducibility for this issue will vary because of differing configs across our frontend clusters and for different domains. However
column11: over time
column12: I expect increasing amounts of Google and non-Google services to stop working because of this. The wget issue noted above is due to a deficiency in wget (lack of SNI support) and is unrelated. I think the problem arises from a failure to clear the OpenSSL error stack in node_: When EVP_PKEY_get1_RSA fails it will leave an error on the stack and that appears to be popping up later in processing. I cannot reproduce this on master and I bisected the fix to d59beb9f686578a3c34606cba294df0fb7d844a9. However
column13: that\'s a wider ranging change that likely fixed the issue by accident or
column14: possibly
column15: masked it for a little longer. As a smaller change that can be back-ported
column16: I\'d suggest checking that the public key is an RSA key before calling  : (Note the extra clause in the condition.) That fixes the proximal issue for me although the problem of not cleaning the OpenSSL error stack appears to be more pervasive."'

b"b' UDP throws unhandled error
column11: even if callback is provided to  .'"

column10: b'b\' If you create a udp4 socket and send some data over it to an invalid hostname (as in the Coffee-Script example below)
column11: then the callback will be called to indicate that an error occurred.  Unfortunately
column12: the udp socket will ALSO throw a top-level exception which kills the entire app. Sample: Run with "coffee ".  You\\\'ll get the following output: And the problem If you uncomment the two lines at the top
column13: and define a "on error" handler
column14: then the callback will be called with the error
column15: and the error handler will also be called
column16: and the program will not terminate (since the socket is never closed.) I would expect that either the presence of a callback _or_ a defined error handler would prevent killing the program
column17: and not require both?\''

column10: b'b" It\'s a backwards compatibility thing but I agree it\'s kind of quirky. I don\'t mind changing it for v0.10 but the thing is that the rules (i.e. what you have to keep in mind when you use the API) become more complex. Currently it works like 1. You need an \'error\' event listener...2. ...unless you pass in a callback...3. ...but the error event should still be emitted when there\'s at least one \'error\' listener because not doing that would break a lot of existing code. The actual change is pretty trivial though:  "'
b'b" I obviously vote to change it.  :)  But
column11: if it doesn\'t get changed
column12: we should at least call this out explicitly in the documentation (if you have a callback
column13: you also need an error handler
column14: or else the whole app could die in a fire.  :)  The stack trace for the uncaught exception doesn\'t tell you anything about where it came from
column15: so tracking this down in a big application with a lot of network IO is not much fun (as I can personally attest to. :P)"'

column10: b'b" I\'m reopening this issue.  I\'ve been thinking it over and I feel this needs a little more consideration.  In particular:That\'s true but streams and datagrams are different beasts.  The former is a 1-on-1 communication channel
column11: the latter one-to-many; you can\'t really compare them. The current API was put together without much thought and it shows.  We won\'t be making radical changes but I think some cleanup is in order and this is one such wart."'

column10: b'b" I totally agree with @bnoordhuis. As an example
column11: take [CoAP]url  It  has all the mechanisms to reuse the same socket for multiple message exchanges with different hosts. I think there are two kind of errors: the ones related generally to the socket
column12: and the ones related to the current message being sent. The general errors should go into the socket event
column13: but the specific errors should not: if sending a message fails for a DNS resolution
column14: the socket is totally fine and can be reused. Moreover
column15: if there were other exchanges going on
column16: the correct behavior with the actual API is to error all of them. My actual solution is to filter the errors codes in the error handler
column17: but it\'s bad and everybody in the very same situation will have the same problem."'

column10: b'b" The current workaround is this: url  I think we cannot support it and stop emitting the error: it\'s good habit to have a listener on the error event of a socket. Here is the best behavior we can support:1. if there is no callback in the send method
column11: then emit as of today2. if there is a callback in the send method
column12: report the error there."'

column11: and now can\'t seem to reproduce it."'

column10: b"b' Can no longer reproduce.  I believe this to be fixed.'"
b"b' Reopening. I still see it from time to time.'"
b'b" I\'ve tracked down the cause. We\'re doing something wrong when sending over handles. What happens is this:1. Parent sends two or more JSON messages to the child
column11: each with a handle (file descriptor) attached.2. The child is not actively reading so the messages queue up.3. When the child catches up
column12: it reads all messages in one go but only receives the first file descriptor.4. The other file descriptors remain in limbo; they\'re either not received at all or end up in the wrong message. In theory
column13: all Unices should be susceptible to this bug but e.g. Linux doesn\'t merge SCM_RIGHTS messages so it\'s never actually an issue on that platform."'

b"b' EventEmitter breaking changes in latest builds'"
b'b" With the change in 4f7f8bbd to initialize the _events object in the EventEmitter constructor
column11: the behavior has changed notably.  This breaks some popular libraries I use (such as \'jake\' for building).  The issue is that now the _events object is on the EventEmitter instance
column12: not whatever \'this\' called addEventListener.  Code that uses a common EventEmitter instance as a constructor function prototype get incorrect behavior now
column13: as all constructed object instances share the same list of handlers. The below simple test works on 0.8.22
column14: and if I build a commit earlier than the above
column15: but fails from that commit on (both added listeners fire for both Task instances
column16: so eventCount is 4).  Simply reverting line 35 in ./ to initialize _events to null (or even comment out that line entirely) fixes the issue.  "'

column10: b'b" Well sadly these JavaScript libs that are now breaking are doing inheritance _wrong_. You don\'t call and set that as the prototype
column11: since that causes the exact problems that you\'re encountering. The constructor of the class is indeed exactly where instance variables should be initialized
column12: so the change was correct IMO. These now broken libs should switch over to using or some other [proper]url  form of inheritance."'

column10: b'b" Might be worth making a note on url  if folks could get bitten by it.  Took me all day to figure it out. (Partly as node-inspector also appears to be broken on the latest v0.10 my Node command-line debugger skills aren\'t quite as brisk)."'
b"b' Added to url '"
b'b\' Thanks.  Just as a note
column11: but the "Correct Style Inheritance" you demonstrate in the page is actually wrong
column12: as you are not calling the parent constructor from the child constructor.  This should be done (as the snippet in the docs at []url  actually demonstrates)
column13: as if the parent constructor isn\\\'t called then any properties it sets won\\\'t get created (e.g. such as _events and _maxListeners on EventEmitter).  Sample below demonstrates. Not a biggy
column14: but if the doc is going to make a point about "Correct Style Inheritance"
column15: it should probably be correct :-) \''

column11: I\'ve set up some really simple server examples. url  In short it seems that sending final writes to might introduce some kind of performance problem. The only difference between these is whether the data chunk is written directly or indirectly via  . In my simple tests
column12: has significantly slower throughput than  . I talked to @isaacs and used a few other load producing methods
column13: url  He suspects there\'s something off about the benchmarking methods instead. If I can help clarify things or try some different setups

column10: b'b\' More thorough data: For ascii and UTF-8
column11: it\\\'s basically always better to do the "hot path" end(chunk) code path in . However
column12: for buffers
column13: it seems to fall off between 96kb and 128kb. Zooming in further
column14: it looks like 124-126 is about the tipping-point
column15: at least on my machine: We could do something like this: but I despise magic numbers and heuristics
column16: and this is both. @bnoordhuis or @indutny
column17: what are your thoughts on this?\''

column10: b'b" I guess this is happening because we\'re copying buffer\'s data into larger one with length information? If so this patch looks good to me."'
b"b' Oops.'"
b"b' Guys
column11: benchmark it on a network
column12: not localhost.'"

column10: b'b" @bnoordhuis Well
column11: in this case
column12: because we\'re zooming in on overhead from our http implementation
column13: it\'s useful to have the benchmark not also introduce another variable. But
column14: yes
column15: to view the scope of the issue
column16: I have benchmarked it over a network.  The effect is smaller
column17: and the variability is much much higher
column18: but after doing 20 runs of each and averaging
column19: the result is roughly the same.  Doing the hot-path becomes less worthwhile when the data size reaches about 128kb."'

column10: b"b' without d62cf59 with d62cf59  '"
b"b' For posterity
column11: the reason I mentioned testing over a network is that packing the headers and the buffer is almost always worth it: copying the buffer adds maybe a few microseconds overhead but an extra TCP round-trip takes several milliseconds if not longer.'"

column10: b'b" Yeah
column11: that\'s why we have Nagle algorithm
column12: right."'

column10: b"b' And see how well it worked.'"
b'b" And was very happy
column11: until we\'ve started building realtime applications."'

column10: b'b" The problem with magic numbers is that they frequently don\'t hold up under variable hardware configurations
column11: especially as things improve. This fix makes me sad. But you guys are way smarter than me
column12: so I don\'t really have a better idea. I guess the perf tests will help if we need to tweak this."'

column10: b'b" @polotek Have you guys tested this in a real environment?  Can you try running the tests against somewhere other than localhost? The more I think about this
column11: the more I think that perhaps @bnoordhuis\'s thinly veiled objection is probably correct.  The tipping point is highly dependent on network topology
column12: since we\'re trading a copy for extra TCP overhead.  At localhost
column13: or over a pretty fast network
column14: 128kb is ideal.  But now testing over a much slower connection
column15: I can\'t see any difference until message size gets up around 8MB. No matter what your network looks like
column16: _eventually_ it\'ll be better to not have to copy
column17: but the slower your connection
column18: the higher that number will be.  It\'d be best if there was a way to avoid the copy in the first place
column19: but I don\'t see how we can do that in a single write() call unless we could either: a) expand the data buffer
column20: in-place
column21: in both directions
column22: which means that we\'d have to have enough room on the SlowBuffer slab
column23: and also not be using that data for anything else
column24: which is (at least) super complicated
column25: or b) use writev() to send multiple pointers at once. Maybe we should just revert this and WONTFIX it?"'

column10: b"b' libuv implicitly supports writev() but it always tries to write() the data immediately when you call uv_write() (provided
column11: of course
column12: there are no pending write requests from previous calls to uv_write(). Order matters.) There are two things libuv can do here:1. Combine multiple write requests into a single call to writev(). Currently
column13: it only uses writev() when the user passes multiple buffers to uv_write().2. Add something like uv_cork() and uv_uncork()

column10: b'b" To be clear
column11: this bug isn\'t affecting anything I\'m doing. I ran into arandom person posting random benchmarks. I tried a simple test myself tosee if I could reproduce. And when I could
column12: I figured I\'d let y\'all knowabout it. If this is a none issue for any real scenario
column13: then I\'m fineclosing it. Though I should say I still don\'t understand the details of why the 2scenarios are different. From what I can see
column14: if is used
column15: then you know that this will be the last write before finishing therequest. And you\'re using that knowledge to optimize the final writeprocess? I don\'t understand the actual optimization yet

column11: but apparently not. :flushed:  The breakage is caused in fromList
column12: which assumes stringMode from whether the decoder is set or not. Ideally fromList should not assume this relation since the assumptions breaks on mixed mode streams where setEncoding is called after some data has been buffered. Regardless
column13: I have updated the patch to simply not call () if the stream has already ended. I have also added a new test case (that fails on master) which explicitly tests stream validity after multiple push(null). Also
column14: I have verified that it passes  !'"

column10: b"b' fs module functions all require callbacks now (v0.10)'"
b'b\' All fs functions now require a callback
column11: where they didn\\\'t in v0.8. This is a backwards incompatible change on an API marked "3 Stable". This only manifests itself when the API calls fail. In that scenario an exception is now thrown
column12: whereas before the error would pass silently. Use case: sometimes you don\\\'t care about errors coming from e.g. ().\''

column10: b'b" Yes
column11: they throw if there\'s no callback to handle the error.  The lack of visibility into failing fs calls on forgotten callbacks caused a lot of problems in v0.8
column12: which is why we added this. You can still ignore errors
column13: but you have to choose to do so by passing in a function that ignores the error. Adding a note to the migration wiki."'

column10: b"b' For the record
column11: this is a deliberate change that was introduced in a804347.'"

column10: b'b\' So API stability means what exactly? The docs say "Backwards-compatibility is guaranteed". But this isn\\\'t true you changed the function signature to require the callback. You can\\\'t just say you don\\\'t require a callback if it\\\'s successful.\''
b'b" Stable != frozen. Stable means \'no breaking changes just for the sake of it\'."'
b'b\' I realize that but I was quoting from the documentation itself. "Backwards-compatibility is guaranteed". You changed the function signatures (and didn\\\'t update the docs to reflect that).\''
b'b" The documentation never specified what effect omitting the callback would have
column11: just that it was possible. I don\'t mind (partially) reverting the change but you\'ll have to give me a good reason
column12: like a production application that is breaking because of it."'

column10: b'b" Haraka breaks because of this change. We create tmp files and unlink them without checking for failure (because logically the only error that can occur is ENOENT
column11: and that\'s irrelevant after successful creation
column12: or I guess EIO might occur
column13: but that probably means everything is f**ked anyway). Multiple paths in the code may unlink the same temp file
column14: making the unlink calls multiple times
column15: resulting in ENOENT which we want to ignore. I can patch Haraka obviously
column16: but this IS an API change you can\'t be arguing that omitting the callback and having an uncatchable exception thrown is an OK thing to do. It doesn\'t happen anywhere else in Node."'

column10: b'b" I can argue anything I want
column11: that\'s a maintainer\'s prerogative. :-) I\'ll see if I can roll back the callback thing in time for v0.10.1. You will have to patch Haraka eventually though."'

column10: b'b" @bnoordhuis @baudehlo What about a deprecation warning?  Then users can still  as they see fit
column11: and they\'ll be given fair warning that it\'ll be an error in 0.12."'

column10: b'b\' FWIW
column11: I agree that this is surprising
column12: and a minor oversight on our part.  The temp file use case makes sense.  However
column13:
errors are ignored by default" is an antipattern that we try to strongly discourage in Node.\''

b"b' Socket not returning to HTTP agent when exception thrown inside of event leading to backed up http pool'"
b'b\' I have found an issue where if there is an exception thrown in the handler of a http response
column11: then this connection will not be returned to the pool until it times out a few minutes later. This causes the pool to backup and can lead to a denial of service attack or other issues in which node will not be able to talk to a host for a given amount of time. Here is a simple proof of concept: This code sample will display "started" 10 times and "response" 5 times (maxSockets is 5) then hang for a couple of minutes until those sockets timeout
column12: then show "response" 5 more times. This exception can be thrown on the response callback or in any of the emit events and will cause a similar issue. This is especially noticeable when you are running a test framework like mocha and on the response you check the JSON object with an assert which throws an exception and causes the rest of the tests that talk to the same endpoint to fail or timeout. For example if you have the following type of code After 5 of these tests fail
column13: the rest will fail with a timeout even though the test might otherwise pass.\''

b'b" So my last two posts (which I\'ve deleted but some may have received emails about them) had bad tests. Here\'s the correct one: In v0.10 this will cause your machine to explode in fire. Though everyone should know the issue has been fixed in v0.11. The reason is because
column11: as you\'ll see if you run the test in master
column12: that in  . Basically
column13: because the data can be immediately written out it immediately queues the callback to be called and never proceeds past the phase of the event loop. Though there\'s a difference between your issue and this example. That is
column14: you\'re reading data. Not writing it. But in the same manner
column15: if the data is able to be read quickly enough (usually this happens when reading many tiny chunks of memory) and Node returns that more data can be read then the callback is immediately queued to be executed. This never allows resources to be cleaned up. I\'ll attempt to write up a quick example for the read case now."'

b'b" Well
column11: there\'s a little more to it than that. Before that commit
column12: would also serialize the entire parent buffer which is probably not what you want
column13: considering that the parent buffer can easily be 10 MB. Open a REPL and type to see it for yourself. The saving grace is that the parent buffer there is only 8 kB. That could be solved by making the .parent property non-enumerable (easy
column14: see the patch below) but that slows buffer creation by about 500%. I\'m afraid the conclusion has to be that we\'re not changing it.  "'

column10: b'b" +1 Thank you we use chris lea\'s Ubuntu package + our own build system for node modules and got bit when the package no longer included the header files. Didn\'t know node-gyp is supposed to put them somewhere since we don\'t use it."'

b'b" -1 from me for reasons I\'ve outlined in #5047 and will repeat here:1. node.h is a rather generic file name that conflicts with files in e.g. python-dev and ruby-dev. Screw up your include path and will include the wrong file.2. Chromium on the BSDs builds against a shared libv8 that installs its headers in / which means has a pretty good chance of picking up the wrong header file. People will just have to get used to node-gyp."'

b'b\' 1. That\\\'s why they lived in  . Those of us using the package do as is convention.2. If that\\\'s an issue we could put node\\\'s v8.h in and use it with  Saying \\\'just get used to our build system" is easy to say when you\\\'re not the one with an exiting build system and 4.5m lines of code.\''
b'b" No one has done any work on this and the reasons I outlined above are as valid as ever.  I\'m closing this as WONTFIX."'

column10: b'b\' There is no value in not delivering header files that are required to use documented public interfaces (e.g.
column11: url The node-gyp "workaround" of downloading its own copy of node and using its headers is unsatisfactory in three critical ways:1. It\\\'s incorrect.  The interfaces specified in the headers used to build an addon must match those provided by the copy of node (and any shared libraries required to use node
column12: if it was built that way) that the addon will be used with
column13: at least to the extent that any public interfaces or definitions may have changed.  When this goes wrong
column14: it leads to failures that are extremely difficult and frustrating to debug.  To the extent that this works at all today
column15: it does so by accident.2. Not everyone uses (or wants to use
column16: or can use) node-gyp.  Leaving this as it is forces everyone to either adopt an approach similar to that of node-gyp (which is incorrect; see above) or to deliver their own frozen-in-time copy of node
column17: v8
column18: etc. headers in their addon source (also incorrect for the same reason).3. It worked in 0.8
column19: so this is a regression.  Even if the change had been documented
column20: which it was not
column21: there\\\'s no reason to break this in 0.10 when it worked before.\''

column10: b'b\' wesolows: +1.  We have a bunch of software that used the headers delivered with v0.8.  I\\\'m just now getting to migrate this stuff to 0.10
column11: and I can\\\'t do it without significant changes to the build system.  With the headers in / as they were in 0.8
column12: there\\\'s no namespace conflict there
column13: since it\\\'s in a node-specific subdirectory that was carved out when 0.8 became widely used.  A component wanting to build against Ruby or Python can skip "-I" and
column15: and so on.\''

column10: b'b" That argument doesn\'t make sense.  One of the things node-gyp does is make sure that add-ons are built against the header files of the node version that will load the add-on. Compare that with site-wide installed headers; if those are outdated
column11: you get build errors if you\'re lucky.  If you\'re not so lucky: spurious run-time failures
column12: aborts
column13: segmentation faults
column14: etc.
column15: etc."'

column10: b'b" So am I correct in understanding that part of the problem here is that doesn\'t work with node-gyp
column11: whereas it did with node-waf (or more specifically
column12: when the headers were being installed to /)? We can likely fix that by adding an include line in the file in node-gyp. Additionally
column13: node-gyp has the ability for you to specify the location of the node header files
column14: rather than having it manually download the tarball and extract the headers. Anybody having issues with the fact that node-gyp connects to the internet should probably be using the flag."'

column10: b'b\' [Edit for formatting;  from a gist didn\\\'t go well.] The proposal is for  to deliver header files into $ for itself and for the libraries against which it is _statically_ linked.  This makes it look like most other packages that allow users to build binaries against them
column11: which helps it integrate into existing build systems.  This doesn\\\'t break how node-gyp works
column12: but allows it to work smoother going forward. (See below for details.) The add-on documentation indicates that users are supposed to include header files like so: It\\\'s helpful to enumerate the various build-time and runtime possibilities
column13: using V8 as the example library: **Case 1: Node built statically linked with V8
column14: PREFIX=/usr**_Delivered files_: /
column16: and related files._Required steps for the user_: User must specify "-I /"._Result_: Add-ons build normally against the correct headers. **Case 2: Node built statically linked with V8
column17: user-defined PREFIX**_Delivered files_: $
column18: $_Required steps for the user_: User must specify "-I $"
column19: but this is SOP for building against a component installed into a custom location._Result_: Add-ons build normally against the correct headers. **Case 3: Node built dynamically linked with system V8
column20: PREFIX=/usr**  (This is the second objection from the earlier comment.)_Delivered files_: $ (no v8.h)_Required steps for the user_: User must specify "-I /"._Result_: Add-ons build normally against the correct headers. **Case 4: Node built dynamically linked with V8 in custom V8PREFIX**_Delivered files_: $ (no v8.h)_Required steps for the user_: User must specify "-I /" and also make sure that their V8 library is on the include path
column21: but that\\\'s SOP for building against a library in a custom prefix. **Case 5: Node add-on built against Python as well** (Python is assumed to have its own "node.h" header.  This is the first objection from the earlier comment.)_Delivered files_: $  v8.h
column22: depending on whether V8 is being statically or dynamically linked._Required steps for the user_: User must specify "-I $" and use or  . **Observation:** it would be better of users were advised to
column23: and if including also included the appropriate header file.  (If built with a static v8
column24: it would  .  If dynamic
column25: it would  .)  In this case
column26: the "Required steps for the user" in cases 1
column28: and even 5 would be nothing at all
column29: and cases 2 and 4 would be reduced to what the user already expects to do in these cases.  Most of the time
column30: it\\\'s likely safe to replace with in an add-on source because the prefix into which Node is installed will usually be on the include path anyway. In all of the above
column31: V8 could be replaced with other libraries that Node depends on.  The full matrix is large
column33: and the same policy should apply to each one. There are a few other cases that come up for libraries like SSL: **Case 6: Node built statically with OpenSSL
column34: add-on wants to link dynamically with OpenSSL.**  In general
column35: this will not work because when the add-on uses an OpenSSL symbol that was built into Node
column36: the version in Node will be used instead of the one from the dynamically linked shared library.  When the add-on uses an OpenSSLsymbol that was not built into Node
column37: the version from the library will be used. This results in mismatched structures being passed to functions
column38: resulting in arbitrarily broken behavior.  (Sometimes it will work by accident
column40: and sometimes data will be corrupted.) **Case 7: Node built dynamically with OpenSSL
column41: add-on wants to link dynamically with the same OpenSSL version.**This will work
column42: with both Node and the add-on using the same set of header files and library files delivered with the system
column43: so there are no symbol or structure mismatches. **Case 8: Node built dynamically with OpenSSL
column44: add-on wants to link statically with OpenSSL.**  This can work
column45: but only if OpenSSL structure are never passed between Node and the add-on. **Case 9: Node built statically with OpenSSL
column46: add-on wants to be builtstatically with OpenSSL.**  Same as case 8. ## What about node_gyp? The suggested change doesn\\\'t break node_gyp
column47: but allows it to use a much simpler algorithm in the future: instead of trying to infer the version of Node for which the add-on is being built and then making sure the source is available (usually by downloading it at build-time)
column48: node_gyp doesn\\\'t need to do anything except make sure that the PREFIX in which node is installed is on the header include path.  It doesn\\\'t need to download the Node source or anything. (Obviously
column49: it will need to fallback to that logic for existing installations.) Importantly
column50: this approach works exactly the same whether you\\\'re working with an official Node release or a custom build of Node.  There\\\'s no need for the nodedir option
column51: or for people to have to think about it. A few people have pointed out that this "works by accident" today: an example case where the current approach is logically wrong but happens to work is Case 3 above.  In that case
column52: node-gyp puts on the include path to pick up node.h
column53: but that causes the add-on to pick up the v8.h in that directory instead of the one in / (which is
column55: the correct one).  This will generate a program with arbitrarily broken behavior at runtime unless the V8 versions in question are "close enough".\''

column10: b'b" @trevnorris My comment was supposed to be about the automated building and packaging Node as part of a broader system
column11: not the development process within Node itself.  Today
column12: if I develop patches to Node (e.g.
column13: to float a local patch before it lands upstream)
column14: all of the consumers of my Node have to build their modules with the nodedir option.  With this proposal
column15: users of my Node build could treat it just like any other Node build with respect to building.  As a result
column16: I think end users of Node would likely never need to use nodedir.  But I wouldn\'t claim to know enough about other use cases to suggest removing it or anything.  (Indeed
column17: it sounds like it\'s still very useful for core developers!)  Sorry for the confusion."'

column10: b'b\' My overarching beef with this proposed change is that it\\\'s basically saying "hey
column11: node-gyp is broken
column12: let\\\'s fix that by introducing yet another build system." No
column13: that\\\'s not how it works if node-gyp doesn\\\'t cover all cases
column14: we fix node-gyp.  We picked node-gyp as _the_ way to build add-ons and we should stick with it. On the subject of  linked against shared libraries: that\\\'s never been the recommended way to run node
column15: there\\\'s a reason we ship our deps in the tarball. If packagers insist on that folly (and note that for example Gentoo is [revisiting the unbundling of V8]url  the best thing we can do is to hide (in the RTLD_LOCAL sense) our dependencies; if an add-on then wants to link against e.g. OpenSSL
column16: it gets its own copy.  The major benefit is that add-ons can evolve at their own pace; they\\\'re not intrinsically linked to node\\\'s deps upgrade cycle. The only dependencies that won\\\'t work for are libv8 and libuv.  Well
column17: too bad linking against versions of those libraries other than the ones we shipped has _never_ been supported. So
column18: still a firm -1 from me.  And because I\\\'m the guy that gets to triage and fix the inevitable fallout
column19: that should count quite heavily.\''

column10: b'b" I apologize if I made it sound like I thought node_gyp was broken.  node_gyp is terrific
column11: and I think this change will allow it to work better in a few less common (but still important) cases.  Nobody\'s proposed another build system
column12: either.  The reason I enumerated those various cases was just to show that delivering headers should not break anybody trying to integrate Node into their _own_ build system
column13: including the Chromium on BSD case that you mentioned
column14: the couple of cases of mine that I alluded to
column15: and @dpemmons\'s. It\'s important for a project to define boundaries on what\'s supported and what\'s unsupported
column16: and it\'s good to have a golden path.  But in this case
column17: we have multiple users trying to do something that was supported in v0.8
column18: was not on the list of things removed in 0.10 but no longer works
column19: and requires significant work for those users to rewrite for 0.10.  You have someone offering to do the work -all 36 lines of code -to fix the problem
column20: and the resulting change hurts absolutely nobody and should be better even for the vast majority of people who will only ever use node_gyp."'

Why isn\\\'t that the default."  I have no good answer for that.  If @tjfontaine is willing to do the work to finish this up, and own it going forward, I am all for it.\''

I am more than a little skeptical that\\\'s actually going to happen; I will go out on a limb and say that there\\\'s overwhelming historical data that if I don\\\'t pick up bug reports, no one will.  I don\\\'t actually mind that all that much but I don\\\'t want to have to support something that I feel is a stupid idea to begin with. If you, TJ and everyone else show yourself to be good bug tracker citizens in the next six months, hey, I might reconsider.\''
node	5112	closed	26	isaacs	2013-03-21 23:50:50	88.85		+1		b'b" @bnoordhuis This removes a common failure case, in fact.1) Your data is skewed by the fact that you generally _do_ pick up bug reports before anyone else does, and that\'s your choice.  Do you have some data showing that when you\'ve taken an extended vacation, there was no bug tracker activity? 2) Picking up every bug until you are feeling burdened and frustrated is not being a good bug tracker citizen.  Please exercise self-care, and know your limits so that you do not get burned out.  Heroics aren\'t helpful in the long run, for you, or for Node. I appreciate all that you do, and I understand that you feel frustrated that you do more than everyone else.  This is me explicitly asking you to do a little bit less. There is no need for you to be the primary maintainer of the build system, and your reconsideration is not required.  Just as you are always willing to send bugs related to streams, npm, and the module system my way, feel free sending bugs related to the build system to @tjfontaine.  I know that you are good at delegating, and the build system is already not your primary responsibility.  To the extent that it affects your workflow, I\'m sure that @tjfontaine will be sympathetic."'

b"b' crypto: fix RSA signature validation'"
b"b' There existed a potential security hole whereby openssl reporting anerror would result in node reporting the signature to be valid. The return value from EVP_VerifyFinal() can be 1 for valid
column11: 0 forinvalid or -1 for error.  It should therefore be tested for == 1
column12: notjust != 0.'"

column11: the next time I see a different one.  All while using the same input file.'"

column10: b'b" I\'m similarly confused by what you\'re trying to do here.  You\'re going to potentially be pushing data back into the stream after it\'s ended
column11: which is not allowed. It doesn\'t currently emit an error
column12: but I\'ll have a patch for that today."'

column10: b'b" Ok
column11: I think that was my issue.  I assumed that read would return a buffer of less than size bytes
column12: when it had reached end of stream.  That doesn\'t appear to be the case
column13: and so I was unshifting into an ended stream and my example somehow was reading the past end of stream."'

column10: b'b\' Aha!  There is a bona fide bug here
column11: but your test is a bit more convoluted than necessary. The problem is that unsets the "reading" flag.  However
column12: really only should unset it
column13: since _consumers_ call unshift() whereas the implementation _itself_ calls push(). I am able to reproduce this reliably with fs streams
column14: but I haven\\\'t yet worked out how to make it happen with a synthetic memory-only stream.\''

column10: b"b' dgram: No way to detect if a port is in use when binding'"
b"b' There is currently no way to request or detect if a port is already in use when binding a UDP socket. One solution would be to have a modified bind
column11: or an optional parameter to force to false during a bind (and the potential to supply a failure callback for more graceful handling). Currently
column12: running two instances of: Demonstrates that both _appear_ to succeed
column13: but only the first running instance will receive unicast messages since there is no way to know whether you are the first
column14: second
column15: or nth bind to that port so there is no way to write a server to receive unicast UDP messages
column16: and _know_ with absolute certainty that it will
column17: in fact
column18: receive them when they are sent to that port. This makes writing any resilient server process pretty much impossible there is no way to elegantly step off and retry (if a service has been restarted and the port is in the process of being freed)
column19: or report an error if the service cannot be bound in a useful manner.'"
