column10: b'b" I\'ve not witnessed the clients being spread between processes on my tests
column11: though that is likely just bad luck they\'ve not been particularly extensive
column12: but I assumed the purpose of port re-use is to allow clustering. But this still leaves the issue of not being able to determine whether another unrelated process is bound to a particular UDP port
column13: which is problematic since having two unrelated services potentially attempting to handle each others requests could be insanely difficult and non-deterministic to debug for an application developer
column14: let alone an end user of such an application. Some way of attempting to ensure the first bind of an application succeeds uniquely
column15: and receive and handle an error if it cannot
column16: would solve this. It would
column17: almost certainly
column18: need some consideration of how it affects the clustering module.  It would require
column19: in that instance
column20: an \'all or nothing\' approach
column21: some way of atomically guaranteeing that the first attempt performs the check
column22: and prevents subsequent processes and binds in the case of a failure to uniquely acquire the initial bind. I\'d be happy to look at the source and contribute a potential patch to this effect
column23: but I was hoping someone with more knowledge of the dgram module could shed some light on whether this was undesired
column24: or problematic for some reason I haven\'t considered."'

column10: b'b" I should probably point out that my testing involved running _separate_ processes
column11: binding to the same port
column12: not a cluster of the same process (the above example was purely a simple example) I was not using the cluster module which resulted in the in the earliest bind receiving all responses for all of my attempts.  I didn\'t test particularly stringently though
column13: as this effect was a bit of a show stopper for the project I had in mind
column14: so I shelved it."'

column10: b'b" IMO sharing a UDP port across the many processes is not a good idea OR not much similar to TCP. Turning back to original issue
column11: It\'s very tricky and the behavior is not consistent among the different operating systems. i.e. you should have root rights under some Linux distros to read ICMP response. Even if you have the ICMP response
column12: it\'s definitely not consistent among the different operating systems and I remember a case where it was acting weirdly under the same operating system.  Also
column13: in case there is a firewall
column14: you won\'t have a chance to know that if that port is listening or not. UDP is kind of send and forget. If you need to make sure the delivery then the basic answer is TCP. This problem can be solved programmatically (in case you have the control over that port)
column15: every new instance pings the port first and waits for the pong to see whether another instance of your app is already listening.  I don\'t see the issue on node side"'

column10: b'b" I think you misunderstand the transport medium is not an issue. UDP port sharing _IS_ the default and only behaviour available I\'d imagine this is to allow clustering (in which case
column11: it makes sense).  But there is no option to attempt to bind an unshared port
column12: so there is no way within the current dgram module to know for certain that your application has unique access to that port at any point (even with a solution to the above some other application could bind the shared address later
column13: but that is a problem for another day). As far as firewalls
column14: and the stateless connection they are not at issue
column15: I just want to be able to know
column16: at startup
column17: whether my service is uniquely attached to a given port
column18: so that I can step off and retry a few times (in case the underlying OS socket free process having a delay)
column19: and then log an error if still unable to uniquely bind. I\'ve tried the approach you mentioned
column20: basically a sentinel process attempting to self connect and report success
column21: but it
column22: by its vary nature
column23: and the nature of UDP
column24: is non-deterministic.How long do you wait?How do you diagnose whether its a network configuration error
column25: rather than a failure to bind?What happens if the end user runs the application twice
column26: and the first responds correctly to the seconds \'are you bound\' request?What if you happen to correctly receive the \'are you alive\' message
column27: due to scheduling luck
column28: but are still subject to port sharing with an unrelated app that will _NOT_ handle subsequent requests correctly? Some of these are solvable
column29: some or really open ended there is no absolutely certain way of finding out without additional support from the dgram module."'

column11: (it seems similar to yours) most of those issues are also open ended internally due to differences among the operating systems.  node
column12: as a cross platform framework
column13: may give more options to developer to let him \'somehow\' develop an alternative solution. But I don\'t think it could still help or behave consistently.  What if another process is listening (shared) that UDP port ? If you are 100% sure your app is the only  etc on that port
column14: indeed you have many options to make \'almost\' sure there is one process at a time listening that port. First two questions you\'ve asked has no answer because of the UDP (cross platform) not Last two questions; There are many other ways to make \'almost\' sure that one process at a time running on a system.  I\'m wondering
column15: perhaps not able to see that the exact additional support needed ? This could be a feature request but I\'m not sure what is or could be expected. "'

column12: my issue is that the currently available  approach which appears to have been chosen to allow the cluster module to work effectively and efficiently (by setting or
column13: when available
column14: on every bind) precludes the ability to solve my problem deterministically
column15: and is the _only_ available option at the moment. To my mind
column16: the solution is fairly simple
column17: perhaps there should be an alternative method to  a udp socket
column18: or ability to specify an option within the existing dgram  ensuring that the underlying implementation does _NOT_ set or when binding a port (and on windows
column19: sets the socket option for cross platform consistency). This would provide the behaviour I\'ve requested above
column20: and answer your first question namely
column21: the ability to exclusively guarantee access to a port
column22: or gracefully handle the situation where that cannot be provided (and prevent other applications from \'sharing\' or \'stealing\' that bind). I mentioned above that the cross platform implications _could_ be intense
column23: specifically because the approach I\'ve suggested gives an example where the cross platform ramifications are simpler than the existing approach (setting or cause far more variance in behaviour between platforms than their omission) though there is no need to modify the existing solution
column24: this should be provided side by side. The approach mentioned would
column25: in all likelihood
column26: break compatibility with the cluster module
column27: though just for these unique bound socket instances
column28: but that seems an acceptable (and solvable) trade off. I believe this is the approach used in Java to ensure consistent behaviour for  s.  I\'ve tested
column29: and they do provide a unique bind
column32: on every platform I have to hand.  So
column33: while I\'m no expert on cross platform socket behaviour
column34: this does demonstrate that what I\'m suggesting is possible. The questions you replied to were merely examples showing some problems that I may encounter trying to solve this in software without additional support in

column10: b'b" Author of that libuv code here.  Libuv\'s UDP port binding behavior is broken by design for reasons of backwards compatibility.  In a nutshell
column11: the reason it works like that is because  v0.4 worked like that doesn\'t mean it isn\'t broken
column12: though. In hindsight
column13: we should\'ve bitten the bullet and turned off SO_REUSEADDR.  That flag doesn\'t share the port
column14: it steals it from the active listener.  It\'s dumb and it\'s caused other projects that use libuv no end of grief."'

column10: b'b" Hehe
column11: that\'s understandable and always easier to spot in hindsight! Are there any plans to offer an alternative mechanism
column12: or fix this behaviour
column13: or is this considered low priority at the moment? It seems like a fairly hard decision is to be made still
column14: since the options seem limited to breaking backwards compatibility
column15: or fracturing the API in some way
column16: and carrying more legacy forward which is why I\'ve not proposed an outright solution
column17: or submitted a PR. If there is already a plan
column18: but the issue is purely of resourcing
column19: I\'d be happy to volunteer some time to help out."'

column10: b'b" I\'d vote for removing SO_REUSEADDR.  Its nominal use case is gracious rolling restarts but in practice it just ends up confusing everyone. Rolling restarts isn\'t why old node versions worked like that
column11: though
column12: that\'s just an accident of history.  When the first UDP implementation landed
column13: it reused some TCP sockets code that among other things set the SO_REUSEADDR flag
column14: not realizing that it has a different meaning for UDP sockets."'

column10: b'b" HI @bnoordhuis! Quick question: what\'s the implication of this when using multicast? Multiple processes could potentially bind to INADDR_ANY
column11: port 1234 and join the same multicast group. Then when someone sends a datagram to MULTICAST_IP:1234 all would get it
column12: which I think it would not happen if we don\'t use SO_REUSEADDR. Am I correct? If so
column13: what do you think about adding some flag to uv_udp_bind (we already take a flags attribute)
column14: having it default to off
column15: to avoid the current confusion?"'

column10: b'b" @saghul: That sounds pretty good to me it makes sense for multicast.  As long as that option was propagated in some way to node as well
column11: that would ensure the multicast use case is workable
column12: whilst allowing the unicast use case to change to the behaviour I had hoped for in my original request. It seems that the effect of has made UDP inconsistent in node anyway I can\'t imagine any non-multicast scenario where any existing software is _relying_ on the behaviour provided by that flag (certainly can\'t be portable)
column13: though its quite possible I\'m overlooking something.  So
column14: definitely a :+1: to removal too!"'

column10: b'b" That\'s correct
column11: multicast is the one case where you want to turn on SO_REUSEADDR."'

column10: b"b' Thanks for confirming Ben! What do you think about my proposal? I can do the libuv side
column11: but I have no idea how it could be propagated into node
column12: given that the API is marked as stable.'"

column10: b'b" Adding a UV_UDP_REUSEADDR flag seems reasonable.  I don\'t really have opinions on what the  API should look like but two (possibly complementary) approaches I can think of are:1. Turning on SO_REUSEADDR in uv_udp_bind() when the bind address is a multicast address.  That\'s not mutually exclusive with UV_UDP_REUSEADDR though you may need a UV_UDP_NOREUSEADDR_NO_REALLY flag too in that case not very appealing.2. Make it legal to call uv_udp_set_membership() before uv_udp_bind() and do an implicit bind based on whether the multicast address is IPv4 or IPv6.  (I think it only supports IPv4 right now but that\'s besides the point.) Option 1 doesn\'t address the case where people bind to a regular address first before joining a multicast group. Option 2 requires that people update their code because right now the documentation says that you should bind first
column11: join second.Stable but not frozen
column12: fortunately.  It helps that not many people use the dgram module and those that do generally agree it sucks; I don\'t think many people will complain if you improve the API."'

column15: I plan to merge it tomorrow. I\\\'ll implement this afterwards and poke you for review ;-)Oh
column16: nice!\''

column10: b'b" I\'m with @domenic on this.  Our goal with the url module is to follow browser behavior.  The WhatWG has been kind enough to make a proper spec
column11: which would have been nice if it\'d been around 4 years ago.  We should follow that spec
column12: since it\'s what browsers actually do."'

column10: b'b" For URI resolution
column11: the HTML 4.01 specification references RFC 2396
column12: which was updated by RFC 3986. The HTML 5 candidate recommendation normatively references only the newer RFC 3986. While the HTML 5 draft does explicitly vary its resolution from RFC 3986
column13: it is limited in scope and in is marked in its rationale for supporting older documents before RFC 3986 that would otherwise be illegal (not a problem for )
column14: and nowhere does it specially handle file URLs
column15: in which drive letters are _supposed_ to be considered a directory. I already use URIs with colons and such characters
column16: in a number of schemes including file with and without an authority
column17: which is a feature heavily used for CURIE
column18: among other uses. Any special behavior would break my application
column19: and could pose security problems if
column20: for instance
column21: certain path segments could modify the authority or the resolved filesystem path. ( mandates that servers accept absolute forms of URIs
column22: too
column23: and any URI

column10: b'b" Indeed
column11: the web has not been following those RFCs for a very long time. Nothing has changed since the early days of web browsers. I\'ve run tests so far in all web browsers plus .NET
column12: and URL handling uniformly figures out Windows drive letter paths correctly. The RFCs are simply inaccurate."'

column10: b'b" If it helps
column11: Node\'s url module already has many improvments over the outdated RFCs that help it match real-world URL resolution behavior. This bug and #5453 are the only remaining missing pieces! But if you check out url  you\'ll see many many other divergences
column12: as we took a URL resolution algorithm designed from the RFC and turned it into one that matched browsers."'

column10: b'b" If the browsers are doing it differently
column11: they\'re doing it wrong. In the HTML specification itself
column12: RFC 3986 is the normative (authoritative) reference in how to resolve and parse URIs. Observing that implementations have done it differently over time is only a reason to make sure that  follows the definition of the URI and not add to the tangle of inoperable implementations."'

column10: b'b" Ah
column11: good catch; I\'ll talk to the appropriate people and get the HTML5 spec updated. Thanks! Edit: Looks like you were just wrong? After asking around #whatwg in IRC
column12: looks like the HTML spec references the URL spec already: url "'

column10: b'b\' The HTML5 spec already refers to RFC 3986? Even if it did define incompatible behavior
column11: being a normative specification means that it can\\\'t be changed
column12: even if such specifications wanted to the URI behavior takes precedence. For reference
column13: here\\\'s a (very incomplete) list of standards or proposed standards that reference RFC 3986
column14: RFC 3987
column15: or a compatible older specification:url  (URIs are resolved against the xml:base)url  (Same here)url  (HTML specifies multiple opportunities to define a document base
column16: and several attributes that are URI references to be resolved against this base)url  (Uses IRI references extensively)url  (and the rest of the DOM family
column17: which exposes URIs resolved from URI references
column18: in HTML and non-HTML XML documents alike; this behavior does not change between HTML and XML).url  (IRI references are allowed
column19: are enclosed in
column20: and resolved against a document base. The default base URI is almost certainly a file URI! These MUST be handled according to RFC 3986
column21: even with Windows drive letters!)url  (Two types of nodes are used to identify resources
column22: URIs and bnodes
column23: both must be well-formed)url  (This ECMAScript API is expected to properly resolve URI references against the document base
column24: usually provided by DOM)url  (and many other documents defined in the CSS family of specifications: URL references are used with string enclosed by and are resolved relative to the document.)url  (A format for expressing absolute URIs in a compact form
column25: used in many Web technologies like RDFa
column26: JSON
column27: and notably Facebook\\\'s Open Graph)url  (JSON-LD practically revolves around URI references)url  (HTTP allows URI references in almost anywhere a URI is used
column28: except in the request-line
column29: in which it must be an absolute URI or an absolute path. These references are resolved against the current resource URI.)url  (The Atom syndication format allows URI or IRI references and uses them in vocabularies defined for both XML and HTTP)url  (The Link header uses URI references
column30: independent of the media type being transferred over HTTP
column32: a .png image can be given an "author" or "self" relation.)url  (OAuth requires URI references are followed properly.)url  (URI templates form URI references)The JSON Reference draft-standard
column33: which allows embedding JSON documents one in another using a syntax
column34: which is commonly going to be resolved against a file URI!The JSON Schema draft-standard
column36: and allows annotating properties as links using URI Template
column37: and allows URIs and URI references
column38: so that Link-compatible metadata may be extracted from the document. Varying the behavior from RFC 3986 would break _all of them_.\''

column10: b'b" @Acubed thanks for doing all that leg work! I\'ve passed it on to the appropriate parties
column11: and we\'ll see updates to those specs soon to reflect web reality."'

column10: b'b" @domenic thanks for your snarky nonsensical help
column11: it really helps contributes to the advancement of the Web. Not. I actually do have a direct line of communication to the authors of many of those standards
column12: they\'ve all told me so far it\'s nonsense. Can we please get on with the reality of the Web now
column13: thanks. RFC 3986 is the single authoritative specification. It is still in STANDARD status; it has not been superseded."'

column10: b'b" What you seem to be missing is that standards reflect web reality; they do not create it. Browsers and other software all implement URLs in a way that diverges significantly from those outdated RFCs; the existence of the URL spec came about because vendors realized this and sought to codify the new reality in a document that they could all refer to for an interoperable implementation of edge cases. It\'s great that you\'ve found places where older documents don\'t reflect that
column11: and we\'ll work toward fixing that. But the reality of the software we work in is different
column12: and that\'s not going to change-breaking many programs that rely on real-world URL spec behavior-just because an older document says so."'

column10: b'b\' I don\\\'t know where you get the impression they\\\'re outdated. RFC 2732 is "outdated"
column11: or to use the industry vocabulary
column12: obsolete
column13: it is superseded by RFC 3986. I I just listed more than a dozen specifications that rely on an exact behavior of RFC 3986. Diverging from the behavior of the _vast majority of specifications_ is what is out of touch. Like I described
column14: HTML5 does accommodate a superset of URIs for reverse comparability like you described
column15: but it doesn\\\'t change its behavior.\''

column10: b"b' There are some subtle differences actually. DOM has already changed: url  HTML has too: url  CSS will soon change too. Do not really know about the rest of the list @domenic mentioned.'"
b'b" Given that there is a plan to update the url implementation to conform better with the updated specs
column11: I\'m going to mark this as defer-to-convergence."'

b'b" See url  Bottom line: We can\'t make this guarantee for HTTP streams.  When \'finish\' emits
column11: it means that it\'s been sent to the socket
column12: but NOT that it\'s necessarily made it to the client successfully. I think that this sucks.  But
column13: if we try to make this guarantee
column14: it\'ll fail for HTTPS streams anyway
column15: and there\'s no way to fix that prior to 0.12."'

column10: b"b' Remove SlabAllocator'"

b'b\' Removing the will allow for more aggressive performance enhancements. EDIT: I have removed a couple commits from the set that weren\\\'t directly related. While this does introduce a small performance regression for requests of small packet size
column11: it seems is exasperating that discrepancy. If the benchmarks are run by hand (running and pointing to the appropriate url) the performance difference is easily below 5%. And this is only for small (i.e. <= 1024 bytes) requests. This patch is a launchpad to several other changes. Some of which include:Allowing the character encoding to propagate down to to remove any redundant object creation.Give more flexibility to callbacks so objects (either buffers or external string resources) don\\\'t need to duplicate memory before being used.Use those custom callbacks to internally buffer key items
column12: such as HTTP requests. This is advantageous because we\\\'d drop the step of creating a buffer then passing it back to  . Instead we accumulate until all headers have been received.Easily create data "pass along" (I\\\'m sure there\\\'s a more correct term for this). Like a pipe
column13: except after pointing the source to the destination in your script the data itself never needs to reach the js level.\''

b'b" () doesn\'t supply a Content-Length header for GET requests with a body"'

b'b\' This is easy for a n00b to run into and it results in a cryptic socket hang up error. Just send a body on a GET request without setting a header explicitly: I ran into this at nodeconf in @isaacs workshop when attempting to simplify a test that sends JSON in the request and response. @domenic
column11: @othiym23 and @mikeal helped me figure out what was going on -it was @mikeal who noticed I was sending a body with a GET. This is legal
column12: according to the HTTP 1.1 RFC
column13: but according to [Roy Fielding]url  it has no  semantic meaning
column14: so "yes
column15: you can send a body with GET
column16: and no
column17: it is never useful to do so". This error can be circumvented by removing \\\'GET\\\' from the list of methods that do not or by adding a header in end() if it hasn\\\'t been set. Or
column18: if it\\\'s better to retain the current behavior
column19: I could add a more explicit
column20: helpful error  message in end()
column21: rather than allowing the request to go out without a Content-Length
column22: which results in the socket hang up error when the server attempts to read the body. Any recommendations?\''

column10: b'b" I don\'t think this is a bug or a feature request. So it should go in the mailing list. Posy back if I\'m mistaken."'
b"b' This is definitely a bug.'"
b'b" So is the problem that chunked bodies aren\'t supported (in the HTTP spec) for GET requests?"'
b'b" p.s. Implicitly adding a header isn\'t going to happen. Use a higher-level request library like or for that."'
b'b" If I understand your explanation correctly
column11: including a body with a GET request is basically undefined behavior. So it technically shouldn\'t throw. But then I think it\'s incorrect to add header values the user didn\'t specify. Possibly just print a warning and continue
column12: similar to how using deprecated code works."'

column10: b'b" If I understand correctly
column11: node is sending a body
column12: but not sending a content-length or content-transfer-encoding header? If so
column13: that is syntactically invalid HTTP
column14: does the http module try not to generate bad syntax
column15: or just consider it a user error? url  GET is not one of the methods that specifies that bodies are unallowed
column16: or otherwise discuss them. OPTIONS similarly has not defined the meaning of a body
column17: though it at least does point out that there isn\'t currently any defined meaning for an OPTIONS body
column18: and that servers that don\'t intend to use the body should feel free to throw it away."'

column10: b'b" @TooTallNate: I\'m not super-knowledgeable
column11: but from what I can tell the spec doesn\'t disallow sending a GET body via chunk-encoding. In this scenario
column12: sending the GET body as chunk-encoded does cause the example to work with no socket hang up error. I\'m happy to submit a pull request for whatever behavior the core team prefers -or to leave it as-is. My main concern is to help with a gotcha for node users. This could be accomplished by making the scenario work by sending the body in chunks or by printing a warning and continuing
column13: as @trevnorris suggests."'

column10: b'b" Not quite. The spec allows it (you can send a body with any request type) but the server isn\'t allowed to attach meaning to it because GET requests are idempotent. Replace \'undefined\' with \'useless\' and you\'re not far off the mark.User error. The http module is pretty low-level (though not as low-level as I\'d like)
column11: it lets you do a lot of things that are not technically legal. I think I\'m in favor of using chunked encoding. I won\'t vouch that all proxies and what have you handle that correctly though."'

column10: b'b" Pull Request #5771 defaults GET requests with a body and no Content-Type header to chunked encoding when in implicit headers mode (if explicit headers are sent
column11: it\'s too late to switch by the time we know if there is a body). (aside: is a bit of a misnomer; might be a better name) I originally created the pull request against master -I apologize if that isn\'t the best target."'

column10: b'b" I believe #5771 is the correct fix. That assumes that it\'s OK for Node servers to socket hang-up on bad clients who send them no header
column11: no header
column12: and a body
column13: which sounds right but it would be good to have some core people confirm. If it\'s not OK
column14: then that would be a separate bug."'

column10: b"b' Another option
column11: instead of using chunked encoding
column12: would be to ignore the body writes the same way we do for HEAD responses.'"

column11: where you can choose what the log is called and where it goes. In my case
column12: we are running in an Active Directory domain environment and some of our folders that are normally local are redirected to a network share so they are always there no matter what computer we log into. Mostly for the benefit of our "My Documents" folder. When looking through the log I found the actual error that I was getting:WixCreateInternetShortcuts:  Error 0x80070005: failed to save shortcut \\\'\\\\\\\\system\\\\users\\\\[myAcctName]\\\\Start Menu\\\\Programs\\\\\\\\ \\\'WixCreateInternetShortcuts:  Error 0x80070005: failed to create Internet shortcutCustomAction WixCreateInternetShortcuts returned actual error code 1603 (note this may not be 100% accurate if translation happened inside sandbox). ## Resolution (for me) Oddly enough
column13: just running an admin escalated command prompt first
column14: and then running the MSI lets it install correctly. I _think_ the difference is that when you double-click on an MSI and it escalates
column15: it runs as and while that account has access to everything on my box
column16: it does not have network access. When I run an escalated command prompt
column17: it is running as **me**
column18: but already escalated (the MSI never needs to ask for escalation)
column19: so it works.\''

column11: @orangemocha
column12: I think I have a clue. I looked at the file properties of your msi to see if I could determine what "brand" it was (appears to be Microsoft\\\'s installer toolkit) to see if I could search for the issue via the installer docs. I didn\\\'t get quite that far since I found [this forum post]url  that probably gives the correct answer regardless of which installer you are using.  In short
column13: some installers give the option of asking the user if they want to install for "Just for me" (not escalated) or for "Everyone" (definitely escalated). If you are installing for "Everyone"
column14: wouldn\\\'t it make sense to put the shortcut for the Start Menu under the "All Users" Start Menu instead of the current user\\\'s? The All Users Start Menu would never be redirected by Folder Redirection
column15: only the logged in user gets redirected. If you really **want** to install to the current user\\\'s Start Menu
column16: the accepted answer points to [another web page]url  which may give you a clue as to how that is done. Since I don\\\'t use the Windows Installer
column17: so I will have to leave the details of how either way that is actually done to you folks... If you tweak the install package
column18: feel free to post a comment back on the forum of where I can find a new MSI and I will be happy to try it out for you.\''

column11: I\'m using a third-party module which ends up calling ()
column12: and I have no way to pass a certificate into the module to be used by its () calls. The only viable option that we\'ve found so far is to set NODE_TLS_REJECT_UNAUTHORIZED=0 or to get a new certificate that\'s rooted by one of the default root certificates trusted by node. Ideally
column13: I\'d like a method by which I could tell node to trust specific certificates in addition to its defaults. I don\'t mind doing some maintenance to make sure my application trusts certificates that I control
column14: but I\'m hesitant to start maintaining my own list of trusted certificates when node is already maintaining a list of trusted root certificates. Interestingly

column16: but its out of date from what Go Daddy currently uses."'

column10: b"b' Explicitly check for RSA keys'"
b'b" I\'m not entirely sure why
column11: but if you provide a Certificate containing an ECC key for SSL Client Authentication and call getPeerCertificate() against it
column12: the SSL connection will reset in some cases upon attempting to send data.  This fix does an explicit check for an RSA key before performing the EVP_PKEY_get1_RSA() call.  That corrects the problem."'

column10: b"b' Thank you for contributing this pull request! Here are a few pointers to make sure your submission will be considered for inclusion. Please see []url  for more information'"
b'b" Investigated a little more
column11: and the connection reset may have to do with the fact that OpenSSL sets an error in EVP_PKEY_get1_RSA if the key type isn\'t RSA.  So it\'s possible that some later code sees this
column12: deals with it incorrectly
column13: and resets the connection.  In any case
column14: the explicit check in this commit works around the problem.  "'

column10: b"b' util: 0.11.x Deprecations in util module break stability level'"
b'b\' This is not an issue related to code
column11: nor is it necessarily a bug report
column12: but I thought it would be useful to start a discussion on the meaningfulness of Node\\\'s stability levels. It seems that in v0.11.x
column13: a number of functions on the util module were deprecated and marked as "Stability 0"
column14: however this contradicts the module\\\'s stability level of 5 ("Locked")
column15: which should imply that the module\\\'s API _cannot_ be changed. Is this considered a regression in the API
column16: given that the module was supposed to be locked? What does a stability level of locked truly mean if the API can still be changed? Would it make more sense to demote the stability level of the util module
column17: given the deprecations and breaking of stability? On a sidenote
column18: is there a replacement for the  method? is not a sufficient replacement
column19: here
column20: since it cannot print without a newline (which many test related tools rely on to print progress
column21: for instance). In this case
column22: the deprecation notice suggests an incorrect alternative method. Should I open a separate issue for this?\''

column10: b"b' same problem here
column11: specially with that warning that not only does not provide a valid alternative
column12: since unconditionally adds the new line and is not compatible with and other universal shell special chars
column13: but such warning breaks any log based on direct stdout print. Maybe the right alternative would be that indeed
column14: to write directly to the
column15: but I see two problems: stability level was a liethe message is not as meaningful as it could have been I hope this will be discussed and eventually fixed pretty soon
column16: my main test framework is broken now ^_^ Thanks'"

column10: b"b' uhm ... never mind
column11: has been fixed with the trick right now. Still a valid issue to me.'"

column10: b'b" A function can be deprecated even if the module it\'s included in is not deprecated.  These functions are marked as deprecated in the documentation
column11: but that doesn\'t mean that the entire util module is deprecated
column12: of course. Working as intended."'

column10: b'b\' @isaacs But the module\\\'s API was marked as "locked". What does the stability level of "locked" mean at the module level?\''

b'b\' The issue here is not that a function can be deprecated in a module that is not deprecated. The issue here is that a function was deprecated in a module that was marked as "locked". Users should certainly expect deprecations from "unstable" APIs
column11: and maybe even "stable" under certain extreme conditions
column12: but I\\\'m not sure what the term "locked" means if it does not guarantee API stability.  I opened this issue for a discussion about the terminology used
column13: not to discuss specific deprecations. It would be nice to actually have the discussion about that topic so these issues don\\\'t crop up in the future.\''

column10: b"b' Fair enough.'"
b'b\' Dropped it down to "API Frozen"
column11: since there have been some additive API changes
column12: and official (in the source) deprecations of things that were only deprecated in the docs previously. Note that the specific details of the module\\\'s stability level is explained right below the number: Like it says on the tin: If it\\\'s not doing what you need
column13: take it to userland.  Relying on has been explicitly not supported since 2013-05-21.\''

column10: b"b' I still believe the deprecation message should suggest a better alternative than since these two operations are not equivalent. Thanks for clarifying though
column11: cheers.'"

column15: due to how the code evolved from the original Contextify code in which was a JavaScript-exposed object. I think it\\\'s [using the abstraction to store a reference to an instance of the C++ class inside a JS-usable  ]url  But it never exposes this JS to JS; instead it stores it
column16: using

column19: to store the C++ instance inside the JS object passed in. There is no need for a JS-usable  .\''

column13: the client should never send a body for delete\'s
column14: because it makes no sense.  i think its pretty reasonable for servers to not expect chunk encoding in delete requests.  in our case

column17: GET requests should all have the same behavior
column18: but they don\'t in nodejs.  "'

UPDATE: Further testing indicates a behavior where it will hangup the connection even after loading has completed.I\\\'m running and have not tried on any other versions (yet).NODE_DEBUG="net http" didn\\\'t reveal anything helpful.This is on OSX 10.7.5 [As discussed in the google group]url  this may only be an issue on OSX. I put together a small gist to demonstrate:url \''

A test case would help because I can\'t exclude the possibility yet that there is a bug in your code somewhere."'

column10: b"b' Node causes uglify-js package to throw ReferenceError on  line 53'"
b'b" This is not a bug in uglify
column11: this is a bug in the  javascript interpreter which is triggered by an uglify source file.  A test case would be nice
column12: but I do not have one; the only way I know to reproduce it is to run the uglify package on an affected node version. To reproduce this bug
column13: try the following: This results in the following error message: Of course
column14: $HOME in the above error message will be replaced with your actual home directory.  The following code begins at the top of
column15: immediately after the license comment: If KEYWORDS is undefined on line 53
column16: that is clearly a bug in the Javascript engine
column17: not in uglify! Many other projects are affected by this bug
column18: basically anything whose transitive dependencies use uglify.  A few reports:  url url url  Several of those issue threads noted that this bug does not occur when _the same_ version of uglify is used with an earlier version of _node_! I did a git bisect
column19: and I determined that the problematic commit is url Unfortunately this is a very complex patch with approximately 1000 inserts and deletions
column20: and I am out of my depth
column21: I know nothing about node\'s internals and learning them well enough to fix this would take a long time
column22: so I\'m filing this bug report instead. As a  user
column23: I think this bug should be high priority.  That is
column24: future numbered releases should either revert the problematic commit
column25: or fix the problem at least well enough for uglify to work as it always has."'

b"b' socket occasionally receives handshake data during upgrade (SSL only)'"
b'b\' We have an issue of node dying occasionally during websocket upgrade request. After a long investigation it turned out it\\xe2\\x80\\x99s because occasionally
column11: after a large number of requests
column12: the socket object will broadcast a \\xe2\\x80\\x98data\\xe2\\x80\\x99 event with the upgrade http request data
column13: after the \\xe2\\x80\\x98upgrade\\xe2\\x80\\x99 event has already been fired \\xe2\\x80\\x93 this causes the WebSocket library to treat the upgrade request as websocket frame (since the data starts with "GET / ..." the library will investigate bit by bit and think the request is a frame with opcode 7 and reserved bits set
column14: causing it to fail).  Initially we thought its the issue within Websocket library but we managed to create a script that will attempt upgrade without it and still get handshake data. Here it 2. when run with batch fails at the same number of attempts (45076 on my 8GB pc / node 0.10.5
column15: 92696 on colleague\\\'s 16GB pc / node 0.10.18 )3. uncomment socket\\\'s pause / resume  to make it trigger on each request4. data event is triggered as soon as we bind to it (replied not set yet
column16: not with  trick though) To read how we got here please check url  Any explanation as to why that happens would be great. Thanks EDIT: sometimes script can stop with ENOBUFS error it seems got it all the time now with node 0.11.7 (also didnt like key for some reason had to move it to separate file)\''

b"b' node_crypto: Add support for AES-GCM modes'"
b'b" This adds support for the authenticated encryption mode **GCM** to node-crypto. **Before**: using aes-128-gcm
column11: aes-192-gcm aes-256-gcm with would work
column12: however decryption with would always throw in  . **With patch**: aforementioned modes are now supported. Users have to use after
column13: transmit the tag with the ciphertext
column14: then use when decrypting. If the data has been tampered with or if no tag is provided during decryption
column15: will throw. The exception thrown from is currently generic. I can make it more  if wanted. **Limitations**: it\'s not possible to add any AAD (additional authenticated data) into the mix (or verify it). This could be achieved by adding another method to
column16: e.g.  . **Other AEAD modes:** The AES-CCM mode cannot be used with the current API because it does not support streaming (the _total_ length of the plain / cipher text has to be known when the first call is made). Unless limiting users to 1 call of was ok
column17: of course.Composite ciphers such as AES-128-CBC-HMAC-SHA1 use a different OpenSSL API
column18: which is rather poorly documented (and only used in OpenSSL\'s TLS implementation as far as I can tell)
column19: so supporting these is not currently in scope of this pull request either. Thanks for considering."'

column10: b"b' http: parse the status message in a http response.'"

b'b\' Add the ability to retrieve the status message (reason phrase) from a http response. This change has a dependency on -parser#152. The dependent change allows the http parser to parse the status message and make it available to node via a callback. This change causes node to listen for that callback and attach the result to the "statusMessage" property of the IncomingMessage object.  While the W3C names this property "reasonPhrase"
column11:
statusMessage" has been chosen to mirror the recent change that allows statusMessage to be written to a http response SHA: 54910044b33a6405c72ad085915a55c575c027fc.\''

b"b' Make TLSSocket wrap Socket instead of inheriting?'"
b'b" The following code works on 0.10.21
column11: but not on 0.11.7: If TLSSocket is passed an unconnected socket with no _handle
column12: it will completely forget about the unconnected socket; if TLSSocket is passed a socket that has a _handle but that has not yet connected
column13: some internal handle throws an error. It seems that those problems occur because TLSSocket tries to inherit from Socket
column14: and for that to work
column15: TLSSocket has to take over the original Socket\'s internal state
column16: and that\'s tricky when the socket hasn\'t connected yet. If TLSSocket were to wrap Socket instead
column17: then this scenario should be fixed
column18: and then the TLSSocket\'s \'connect\' event could fire when the TLS session has been established
column19: instead of firing as soon as the underlying socket is connected."'

column10: b"b' stream: writes can return false but forget to emit drain'"
b'b" If a write is above the high water mark but _write still manages tofully send it synchronously
column11: _ can be adjusted downto 0 synchronously with the write that returns false
column12: but \'drain\' willnot be emitted until . If you then issue another write before  happens which is short
column13: will be reset to false
column14: and the drain event will never fire. Making matters worse
column15: if you have a 0.8-style Stream piped into this writable stream
column16: this means the source stream will get paused (due to a write returning false) and never resumed. Eg
column17: you would expect the following code to exit 0
column18: not fail.  It exits 0 if either of the two write calls are removed; you need the big one followed by the short one for the issue to occur.  "'

column10: b"b' I believe the issue is in in url  The flag is reset by the second write before the drain event is fired. It looks like previously the code did the right thing by only setting the flag to true
column11: never resetting to false: url  changed in url  in what looks to be an unrelated refactoring.'"

column10: b'b" By the way
column11: the reason that this only affects piping from 0.8-style streams and not from 0.10-style streams (or
column12: well
column13: people doing their own flow control implementation) is that is careful to immediately stop writing to a stream after returns false
column14: whereas will happily send any incoming data along to the destination even if it thought that it already paused the source.  That\'s why people who are only using 0.10-style streams and are only using pipe (ie
column15: no manual handling of return values) aren\'t seeing this. But I think it actually can occur just using 0.10-style streams and
column16: if you have stranger topologies.  For example
column17: if you have TWO source  s and and one destination  .  And you run both and  . Let\'s say that sends a 16500 byte write to  . This will cause to return false
column18: so increments its and won\'t send anything else to until it emits drain. But since there\'s no event associated with returning false
column19: has no idea that there\'s anything wrong with writing to  .  If happens to send a small write to before
column20: will clear its flag and never notify that it\'s time to continue.  Clog!"'

column10: b'b" I now believe this may be an issue with the garbage collector change is Node v10. I ran the code below using node v0.8.5 and node v0.10.22. In v0.8.5 the memory starts at about 35Mb and never increases significantly. Running with trace-gc shows that it is doing Mark-sweep collections very frequently and successfully collection garbage. Running with v0.10.22 shows the process increasing in memory usage by about 30Mb per second until it the box runs out of memory. Looking at the memory collections

column10: b'b" Not all the default upper limit on most systems is around 1.6 GB.  You can limit it further with old_max_space_size=n where n is in MB. I see you\'ve already figured it out but to confirm
column11: yes
column12: the garbage collector in v0.10 allocates memory more aggressively.  A common complaint about the GC in v0.8 is that it\'s slow (and it is)
column13: that\'s why the GC in v0.10 trades space for time."'

column10: b"b' Domain#exit() clears domains stack'"
b'b\' I was reading through the source in  and came across odd behaviour. I\\\'m not sure if it is intentional
column11: but it is surprising and undocumented.. The domain module maintains a stack of domains to allow for nesting. Calling on a domain pops it (and any contained domains) off that stack. If the domain that is called on is _not_ on that stack
column12: the entire stack is cleared in the process of looking for it. This happens if the domain has already had called on it or if has never been called on it. According to the documentation
column13:
Enter and exit can be called an arbitrary number of times on a single domain." but clearly this has side effects outside of the domain in question. I\\\'m not sure of the consequences of this, but I thought it weird enough to report just in case. Results in: /cc @sam-github @piscisaureus \''
node	6819	closed	1	othiym23	2014-01-08 01:32:59	27.97		+1		b'b" This is by design, but the reason why is a little subtle. If you think about how try-catch-finally works in synchronous code, a throw bypasses the normal flow of execution and bypasses any contained catch statements. If you think of domains as an async analog of try-catch, the analogy should be clear. I agree it\'s surprising to encounter in the code, but I\'m not sure documenting it in the API docs would be useful. Maybe a PR with some clarifying code comments?"'
node	6819	closed	2	rmg	2014-01-08 01:32:59	1103.38		+1		b'b" Using the nested  analogy, above seems to be causing throw to bypass all catch statements _everywhere_, contained or otherwise. That block closing behaviour can\'t even be expressed with  because it would be a syntax error. Am I interpreting your analogy correctly?"'
node	6819	closed	3	othiym23	2014-01-08 01:32:59	18.47	+1			b'b" Yes, and your example identifies a bug in  \'s logic that I was too dense / tired /  in the middle of traveling to notice (sorry!), which is that should verify that the domain has been entered (i.e. is in the stack) before it starts popping nested domains off the list. That should be fixed! In practice, very little code uses and directly, and if you\'re using  , it will ensure that nested domains are entered and exited properly. A couple frameworks (including and manipulate domains directly, and I guess until this issue gets addressed the best advice I can give is to be careful about matching up domain entry and exit."'
node	6819	closed	4	rmg	2014-01-08 01:32:59	7.37			+1	b'b" Thanks for the confirmation :-) I hadn\'t realized the plumbing nature of and when I first posted. Since all use it correctly it makes sense that it hasn\'t been an issue. I\'ll try to cook up a PR for this, it seems simple enough."'

column10: b'b" I\'m uncomfortable with rolling ES6 support out piecemeal. As a tooling engineer
column11: this creates a feature matrix for support that just seems nightmarishly complex. Each additional language feature adds in more conditional logic to the various bits of my codebases that need to accomodate specific features. Also
column12: because there\'s no rigid correlation between the (implicit) version of JavaScript implemented by a given version of V8
column13: the version of V8 in the runtime
column14: and the version of Node
column15: this means that new features are going to be trickling out over time
column16: which implies the possibility that there will be more tests necessary for specific point releases of Node to deal with changes in the underlying language. If the versioning were a little more lockstep
column17: I\'d probably be more comfortable with this. In general
column18: I\'d be more comfortable waiting until V8 is confident enough in their implementation of the standard to drop the flag than opting the community in gradually."'

column10: b'b" I can see @othiym23\'s point of view. Counterarguments:Turning on known-safe features helps avoid people turning on and using itself
column11: which would opt them into known-unsafe features (like proxies or similar).It\'s pretty unlikely all of ES6 will be implemented in V8 at any point before
column12: say
column13: 2018. (Judging from time to ES5 implementation from spec completion
column14: plus a multiplier for the relative complexity of ES6 vs. ES5.) More likely
column15: they will wait for the spec to be pronounced final
column16: then turn on all the features they\'ve completed
column17: which will still be a piecemeal selection."'

I\'m sure we\'re not alone in this respect. People building platforms on top of Node are strongly affected by this decision.I don\'t find this argument very compelling. V8 gives you more fine-grained control over which features you enable via the various switches

column10: b'b\' A friend of mine started doing some things in  and he said he really really wants to write his code "semantically correctly" as in "using correct container for the job". After trying out and this contructor he basically stated that JavaScript is broken and without hope. It took me some time to explain that he should not take unstable features for granted and that is why unstable features such as harmony should not be enabled by default. Set is probably one of the "hottest" wanted features and imagine how many bugs could be triggered by later fixing the previously broken behavior if were to be introduced by default in its current state. I guess it is not possible to introduce these new features in a module scope only?\''

b'b\' Adding the features piecemeal causes a compatibility nightmare similar to the Python 2.x releases. As different features stabilize you enable them which means that all modules using those features only work with that release forward. These changes are higher impact than any of the changes we\\\'ve seen in core since 0.8 and make compatibility between releases a much more complicated story. IMO it would be much better to say "this is the ES6 release" and enable everything when it\\\'s ready. That would mean only one forward compatibility break for the module ecosystem to deal with and only one node version people who are using these features have to worry about hitting when they see ES6 features being used in a module.\''
b'b" @domenic I have the exact opposite perspective on people running with :) Only crazy people are running that in production. Which is good
column11: we need crazy people
column12: and we need people who are living on the edge and experimenting
column13: that\'s why the features are available _at all_ behind a flag. For the people who are experimenting it is actually beneficial for the community for them to be opting in to _more_ unstable features because that\'s the only avenue we have for testing
column14: early usage
column15: and feedback. Core\'s primary concern should be maintaining stability for the majority of the module ecosystem and production users and not stabilizing the people who are living on the edge and helping us everyday by testing unstable features :)"'

column10: b'b\' Note that unlike Python 2/3
column11: ES5/6 is backward compatible in every way. (No ES5 code will break by turning on ES6 features.) In general
column12: I would encourage moving away from a version-number based way of thinking. Much like every other web spec
column13: ES is evolving toward a model that does not consist of rigidly-defined versions
column14: but instead modular features being added periodically
column15: with interplay between the spec and engines informing evolution. The version number is not very meaningful. For example V8 will likely ship  (ES7) before direct proxies (ES6). Now. If you want to abdicate responsibility for deciding when something is "ready" to V8
column16: i.e. wait until they turn on the flag by default
column17: that\\\'s a fine and consistent approach. But we shouldn\\\'t pretend they\\\'re going to do an "ES6" version suddenly. It\\\'s going to be just as piecemeal as what we are contemplating here.\''

column10: b'b\' New ECMAScript versions tend to get implemented over a very long stretch of time if we decide to wait until v8 implements the entire spec
column11: we may be waiting for years for some of its benefits.  I also don\\\'t think
column12: however
column13: that providing a whole bunch of piecemeal harmony flags is a good idea either. The node team should make the decision on what harmony features can be considered "stable" as of v8 v 3.23
column14: and implement those into node core.  Other non-stable features can continue to be accessed by the harmony flag.  Additional harmony features can be added as they become more stabilized
column15: but only in the next major version (i.e. freeze the harmony features that are added in 0.12
column16: and then no new harmony features can be added until 1.0
column17: then 1.2

column10: b'b" @seishun please proceed. I did start some initial design work offline but got stumped with direction and learning curve with C and was then distracted by other higher priority initiatives.  Below are some of my thoughts on this. The challenge is to design it so that it is both fast and useful. To be useful
column11: it should allow for generating a CRC from a stream from JavaScript side. To do this
column12: we would need to use zlib\'s crc32.c::crc32() and ideally store the running checksum in C++ side rather than marshaling the running checksum back and forth from JavaScript side. The JavaScript side would only be pushing buffers of data through to crc32.c::crc32() from a stream on the JavaScript (userland) side.  There are use cases where I would like it to act against a file directly and it would be interesting to see how much faster it would be to implement a simple wrapper for minizip.c::getFileCrc(). This should be the fastest way to go and could be a good litmus test to see how much extra compute time is taken by the JavaScript and marshaling side of  and expose opportunities for optimization in the stream based approach."'

b'b" Every seasoned programmer understands the importance of API stability. The async coding style using  can easily put a  programmer at stake of breaking API contract.  built-in function only makes it more vulnerable. My point is elaborated in a [stackoverflow question]url  I have tried [Node Fibers]url  and ES6 generators in vain because my problem is more fundamental than those techniques can handle. column11: I think the easiest workaround is to implement a sleep function in Node. Unlike a sleep function in languages that support multi-threading
column12: the sleep won\'t block the thread
column13: instead
column14: it yields to allow other events in the event loop to be handled. The re-entrance to the call  is triggered by a timer. Of course

b'b" Generally speaking seasoned Node programmers know to make your API asyncfirst
column11: and sync later. IMO the sync API should only be considered stable ifyou control the code start to finish. Otherwise it should never leave bepromoted to a stable API.AFAIK synchronous functionality was only added after the fact
column12: after muchcommunity input. Though use of those APIs has never been promoted by ourthe core team.This is impossible to do without violating variable declaration stability.Since implicit global variable changes could occur during this time. Andalso without integrating yield into core. Which I vehemently oppose (queueargument from Dominic ;-). Even if we did decide to introduce yield into core then a massive amount ofrefactoring would need to be done to preserve state on things like thenextTickQueue processor. Sorry
column13: this is a feature request that I don\'t see happening."'

column10: b'b" You\'ll run into issues if you haven\'t taken the necessary steps to preservestate on things like the nextTickQueue. Consider the following: var thing;(function runMe() {  doWork(thing);}); thing = getStuff();sleep(2000); In this case doWork() is going to fire before thing is assigned. Becausecontinuing on through the event loop the nextTickQueue will continue toprocess until the queue is empty. Which will fire runMe(). This is just one example. IMO the complexity for the feature is too great."'

column10: b'b" I see what you\'re saying... but the reality is that the implementation in node is provided by V8
column11: so there\'s really not much we can do about it. If it weren\'t already provided by V8 then it probably wouldn\'t be in node by default in the first place. There\'s lots of things in JavaScript that can block the event loop
column12: but I think being educated about it
column13: and knowing when to use something async vs. something sync is the better way to go about it. We\'re not going to start adding magical sync-looking-but-really-async functions to node to try to prevent users from shooting themselves in the foot. Personally
column14: I\'d recommend to use  to make your async code _feel_ sync."'

column10: b'b" From a more architectural standpoint
column11: yes
column12: you may _want_ the large-ish JSON object
column13: but if it is large
column14: you probably would want to do some kind of streaming work on it while it\'s on the way in
column15: rather then buffering the entire thing into memory and then parsing it. You can architecture your app to be a lot more memory-efficient this way."'

column10: b'b" I\'m reopening this
column11: so long as Node\'s internal IPC mechanism relies upon JSON I think it\'s reasonable to explore a way to provide async JSON without changing the semantics of the runtime we\'re relying upon. That is to say we want to use V8\'s but off-loop. In any event
column12: I\'d entertain PRs from interested people along with some good data behind some of the costs associated with it since it won\'t necessarily be free."'

column10: b'b" The complexity of doing this isn\'t going to be trivial. IPC won\'t workbecause that will end up re-serializing the JSON before it hits the mainthread. Also you\'ll need to handle security tokens of the object since theObject will need to be created in another Isolate. It\'s not like you could just uv_queue_work() and pass the char\\\\* and tell v8to parse the JSON then pass back a direct pointer to the Object\'s memory. Anyways
column11: you get the idea. TBH I like the concept
column12: but it won\'t be easy."'

column10: b'b" @vkurchatkin What\'s costly? Is it parsing
column11: or the construction of the result? If the cost comes primarily from the construction of the result and if we have no choice but do it in the main thread
column12: it won\'t help much to offload just the parsing to a separate thread and build from an intermediate representation. My gut feeling is that parsing must be really cheap. There are two problems here: 1)  takes CPU in the main thread and 2)  blocks the event loop. We are trying to solve 1. Maybe we should solve 2 instead by keeping all the processing in the main loop but yielding periodically to the event loop. Not as good but maybe good enough."'

column10: b'b" @bjouhier that\'s the question. My hypothesis is that actual parsing is pretty costly and this approach is beneficial for large JSONs. Also values can possibly be created lazily. "'
b'b\' First of all
column11: object sharing among the Isolates not possible (because of heap memory indexes
column12: GC levels and even optimizations). a very basic example; for the above code V8 optimizes the operation and **"may not"** do much thing (since we don\\\'t use dict) and while doing this
column13: it doesn\\\'t check anything on other Isolates. Eventually
column14: sharing an object among the Isolates produces unexpected results. BTW
column15: it doesn\\\'t matter if the external JSON parser etc. is efficient or not. You will end up blocking the main thread even more. :The object subject to  needs to be parsed and then be transferred into an external memory block during the current thread. (heavily blocking Object:Get / Has / IsThatType or NULL / memory allocations etc) When the \\\'stringify\\\' is completed
column16: the result must be copied back to current heap. (not for free blocks the main thread again)  :Parsed string needs to be filled into V8:Object . Lots of "Set"/"New" calls on the native side. Unfortunately they are very expensive. (heavily blocking) For many cases it is visibly faster if you could simply move string to JS side and parse there instead of creating a new Object on the native side. Especially when the members of that Object have long strings. \''

column12: it actually slows things down. This sounds like people want streaming parsers
column13: but are not throttling the connection / input the the streaming parser. Since Isolates are not able to share Objects across threads we would have to reconstruct the object manually either way... I am unsure how you would speed this up. You could remove the minimal fluff while parsing out of thread (quotes
column14: colons
column15: braces
column16: brackets
column17: commas...)
column18: but that would not really save much time since you would have to move the strings to be V8::String when you make an object. Inverse applies during stringification.\''

column10: b"b' Maybe implement streaming JSON parser in node core then?'"
b'b" @Dream707 why? It won\'t make it faster."'
b'b" @indutny but at least it won\'t block main thread "'
b'b" You could do non-blocking stuff in user-land too. Also it is pretty questionable
column11: how well it\'ll perform. Especially considering flickering back and forth from worker thread to the main loop."'

column10: b'b" Reasons why off-loading parsing to a thread won\'t help much have been outlined above by @obastemur and others.  I suggest closing this."'
b'b" I\'ll let @tjfontaine decide on this one ;)"'
b'b\' @bnoordhuis do you mean "Lots of "Set"/"New" calls on the native side." ? Because you definitely can avoid these. \''

b'b" That\'s not quite what I mean.  There are two cost centers when parsing JSON: actual parsing and converting parsed input to JS values.  You can farm out the first one to a worker thread but not the second one. I\'m fairly confident (having profiled it with perf in the past) that of the two
column11: rematerializing JS values is much more expensive than parsing
column12: doesn\'t matter if you\'re going through the V8 API or not.  So while you can spend a lot of time optimizing the parser
column13: the biggest cost center still runs inside your main thread.  Never mind that the vagaries of thread scheduling means you\'ll add variable (as opposed to deterministic) latency to your deserializer. (For the serializer
column14: it\'s even worse because you cannot access V8 objects from outside the main thread.  Ergo
column15: it\'s not really possible to off-load the work.) Having said that
column16: here is a semi-plausible way of implementing an off-thread serializer / deserializer.  The main thread would need to release the V8 isolate using a v8::Unlocker right before entering epoll_wait() and reacquire it after returning from the system call.  That way
column17: the other thread can acquire the isolate and start serializing or deserializing away. However
column18: that will only marginally improve matters because if the system call returns before the worker thread is finished
column19: the main thread will block until the worker is done. A secondary issue is that Locker and Unlocker objects are backed by a system mutex and that opens the usual can of worms about unfavorable thread rescheduling when the contention rate is high."'

column10: b'b" I don\'t really see how this can help
column11: if only one thread can work with isolate. That means that no js can run in parallel with  (not even other ). Or am I missing something?"'

column10: b"b' Original message was about to making it async
column11: not faster.'"

column10: b"b' @Dream707 actually it is about blocking less. If you just want async
column11: you can split large json into pieces and feed it to streaming parser using to iterate. But in total this will block even more.'"

column10: b'b" How is it done with databases that not optimized for async operations? With file IO? I\'m sure it is not first time this problem rises
column11: so it should be solved somewhere already."'

column10: b'b" @Dream707 it\'s clear how this can be done
column11: but the question is would it be beneficial at all. Here how I see it: the process has three phases:input dematerialization
column12: that is taking JS objects and converting them to simple structures
column13: copying buffers
column14: etc;processing;output materialization
column15: the opposite of dematerialization. The first and the third phase should be executed on v8 thread
column16: while the second can be handed to  . If we compare executing all three phases on a single thread with off loading processing to other thread
column17: it\'s obviously a win (not taking cost in account). When processing actually involves some blocking IO it can really take a long time
column18: while  can be really cheap (like in case of SQL query). So
column19: in case of integration 3rd party blocking library we\'ve managed to make possible something that wasn\'t possible before and even did our best to block less. What about performance
column20: we don\'t have actually something to compare with. With pretty much everything is different:1. we don\'t have these three phases
column21: so everything should be reimplement;2. processing doesn\'t involve IO
column22: so it\'s possible that materialization will be more expensive
column23: than processing;3. we have native implementation which uses internals and is probably really fast
column24: so it can happen that it\'s faster than ad hoc materialization could ever be."'

column11: accidentally clicked the button before finishing -The point of this is a tracking issue to encourage people to submit a PR that demonstrates the implementation and usage for Node core. There are multiple reasons to want this for core and to export an interface for users that is canonical for them to rely upon. It\'s a difficult line to walk between what belongs in core and what belongs in user land. But one of the easiest ways to identify that is if Node core itself could make use of that functionality. So while there are many opinions here
column12: and many observations about what the ramifications are of having that pattern in core -there hasn\'t been anything brought to the table yet to comment on and iterate on. But this tracking issue is staying open until it has been fully explored for use in core."'

column10: b'b" Doesn\'t really matter to me whether this is in core or in user-land but it would be nice to have it. First question is what?1. do we want to offload processing to a worker thread?2. do we just want to make parsing interruptible to avoid blocking the event loop? From the exchanges above (and I\'m completely following Ben on the fact that pure parsing part should be the cheap part)
column11: option 1 is a very difficult path. Option 2 is much easier. We could do it with an API like: This is completely synchronous and everything is done in the main thread but it allows you to update the parser from events. Then
column12: when you receive the event you can retrieve the result. Wouldn\'t this be sufficient?"'

You might as well implement a fast scanner that can interpret the JSON andindex each sub-object. Then use string slice to parse each chunk. While itwould be possible to offload the indexing of the JSON to a worker thread
column12: the indeterministic nature of doing so means it\'s highly unlikely to haveany performance improvements.IIRC V8 does offer an API that allows users to interrupt long runningscripts so the user can act. But it would be impossible to store the stackof currently parsed data so it could be resumed later."'

column10: b'b" I did a quick implementation of the idea in pure JS. It is 2.65 times slower than native when parsing in one shot and about 2.8 times slower when parsing incrementally: url  A C++ implementation can probably reduce the gap with but I don\'t have any clue of what can be gained. Note: implementation still needs work (unicode escape sequences
column11: stricter syntax checking
column12: no profiling yet). I just wanted to get a feel for performance."'

column10: b'b" @trevnorris My previous comment was an attempt to re-position the problem. To clarify I don\'t think that trying to offload parsing to another thread is a good idea. On the other hand
column11: a parser that you can update incrementally from events and that can deliver the result without blocking seems more useful. "'

column10: b"b' @bjouhier this problem is solved by few packages url  url  Such approach makes sense if you actually have a readable stream
column11: from both memory and less blocking standpoints. But manually splitting a buffer into chunks and iterating asynchronously is lame.'"

column10: b'b" @vkurchatkin You\'re right
column11: jsonparse does exactly what I described earlier (did not know about it). But i-json is a lot faster than jsonparse on my test file (1660 ms vs 8100 ms). If we could have something like jsonparse / i-json with performance that\'s very close to native we could handle lots of JSON parsing scenarios without blocking the event loop and with less memory overhead than today. Normally the data comes in small chunks and that\'s what you want to handle without blocking. Why worry about the case were the whole string is already in memory? As you say
column12: it can be handled by splitting and iterating asynchronously and that\'s lame. But what\'s lame is not the parsing in this case
column13: it is the fact that the whole JSON text has been accumulated in memory in the first place. If you want to process a large JSON feed
column14: for ex a log stream
column15: you want to update the parser as you receive chunks (and discard the chunks) and you want the parser to emit an event every time it has recognized a complete top level entry in your feed. That\'s exactly what jsonparse does
column16: and that\'s what I want to do with i-json (I did not implement the emitting part yet but that\'s easy to add). Delegating JSON parsing to a worker thread seems to be a very challenging problem. From the previous discussions
column17: it does not seem like it will help much because V8 more or less imposes that you materialize the result from the main thread. And materialization is the costly part. I did a bit of timing with i-json: parsing only accounts for 300 ms of the 1660 ms
column18: the rest is materialization. Also
column19: the 300 JS parsing time is less than half the total time taken by native  (622 ms)."'

column10: b'b\' Hi rektide
column11: I added clarinet to the test. It is faster than jsonparse but it does notmaterialize the result (it just emit events) so the test is unfair. It isabout 3 times slower than i-json (which materializes the result). JSON parsing is an area where I\\\'m not ready to trade pure perf for fancyfeatures. So what I\\\'m investigating here is how close we can get to native with an incremental parser. With i-json
column12: I get 2.5 ~ 3 timesslower. clarinet and jsonparse are more around 8 ~ 13 times slower. Lookslike the next step will be C++. column10: b"b' FWIW
column11: I made good progress on a C++ implementation of the incremental parser. Typical run output: So on average i-json is 1.63 times slower than  on a full parse and 2.05 times slower on an incremental parse. This is significantly better than the JS implementation (was 2.65 and 2.8 times slower). Getting faster is starting to be challenging because  is using internal V8 functions to build objects and optimize the allocation of ascii-only strings. The allocation of  and the assignments to  slots account for 66% of the overall processing time in the i-json C++ implementation (with my test data). The allocation of strings alone account for 38% of the time.'"

b'b" @tjfontaine Excellent decision to keep this open and explore the possibilities. Thanks. Blocking on is a common gotcha. Yes
column11: it\'s CPU not IO-bound
column12: but it\'s extremely prevalent and new developer ignorance can have a deleterious affect on their perceptions of node\'s performance or single-thread model due to latency compounding in concurrent requests. I see value in a non-blocking async API
column13: where processing is backgrounded off the main thread and amortized across event-loop ticks: Having a callback (non-stream) version is analogous to and  ; Callback APIs are simpler. One can conceive of a scenario where a JSON payload must be acted upon as a whole. In this case
column14: streaming provides no benefit and an async API avoids latency compounding in concurrent requests. Background-ability / deprioritization is a common pro-thread anti-node argument
column15: so I see benefit in addressing this. That said
column16: the value of a core async is independent of the implementation feasibility
column17: which I leave to the experts."'

column10: b'b" It\'s definitely not a good idea. You will have a parsed object in a different process. Then what? How do you pass it back?"'
b'b" If it were that easy we wouldn\'t be requesting it in core ;-)."'

b"b' And the same holds for parsing in a separate thread. V8 does not allow you to materialize the result directly from another thread (*). So you are a bit stuck. I see two ways to handle JSON parsing asynchronously:1. You do all the work from the main thread
column11: but you do it incrementally. This way
column12: other events can interleave with your parsing. This is the approach I took with i-json.2. You parse in a different thread (and a different isolate) and you use [structured cloning]url  to transfer the result to the main thread. Overall
column13: you will consume more CPU (because of the extra cloning) but most of the CPU will be consumed in the worker thread and you should reduce CPU usage on the main thread. Best would be to combine the two approaches to 1) materialize incrementally and 2) reduce CPU usage in the main thread. (*) Parsing is very different from  or doing crypto computation because the result is a tree of JS objects
column14: not a string or Buffer (that you can pass across threads).'"

column10: b"b' Another solution is to parse into a very efficient binary format (BSON or variant thereof) in a worker thread and then materialize from binary in the main thread.'"

b'b" @vkurchatkin @asilvas @bjouhier: Fascinating. These insights are sensible and I see the challenge more clearly. If the primary block is memory-managing a JavaScript Object with unknown value characteristics
column11: then working with BSON is quite compelling. However
column12: I see an exciting implication arising. Although JSON is beautifully convenient
column13: it may not be what I really need in my applications. Cool
column14: thank you! Otherwise
column15: am I overlooking some alternative to handling JSON in
column16: for instance
column17: REST API requests? Are most REST API\'s that exist in production suffering from this bottleneck? Is it common to hack together a parsing strategy?"'

column10: b'b" In theory BSON sounds like an interesting workaround (read: not a solution)
column11: but native BSON processing is actually far slower than JSON -run the benchmarks if you like. Any solution involving serialization will likely be a nonstarter. Technically it might be possible to build a native module that handles passing the object references between threads (including thread safety) for serialization
column12: but it\'d probably be quite fragile unless it\'s in core."'

column10: b'b" @tracker1 I don\'t get how JSON3 would help. I looked at it and did not see any incremental parsing in it. Did you try [i-json]url  It is incremental and you can control the size of the chunks. There is a C++ implentation for  and a fallback JS implementation. I did a quick bench of JSON3 against the i-json C++ parser on node 0.12 OSX: JSON3 is 2 times faster than the i-json C++ parser but this is because JSON3 uses the native (with a tweak which makes it even faster).If I tweak JSON3 to use its JS implementation instead of the native (returning false at line 214)
column11: then JSON3 is 1.6 times slower than i-json\'s C++ parser.JSON3\'s JS parser is 40% faster than i-json\'s fallback JS parser."'

column10: b"b' Cluster: fix shared handles on Windows'"

b'b" This is the Node side of the fix for Node\'s cluster module on Windows.url  The other required part isurl  Windows and Unix return certain socket errors (i.e. EADDRINUSE) atdifferent times: bind on Windows
column11: and listen on Unix.In an effort to hide this difference
column12: libuv on Windows stores sucherrors in the bind_error field of uv_tcp_t
column13: to defer raising it atlisten time.This worked fine except for the case in which a socket is shared ina Node cluster and a bind error occurs. A previous attempt to fix this (url url ) was flawed becaused in an attempt to relay the error at the JS levelit caused the master to start accepting connections. With this new approach
column14: libuv itself is relaying the bind errors
column15: providing for a uniform behavior of uv_tcp_listen."'
