column10: b"b' test-http-dns-fails breaks if DNS server send redirects answers on invalid hostnames'"
b'b" In test-http-dns-fails
column11: the test performs two HTTP requests and makes sure that:1) The response callback is not called.2) The error event is emitted. Here\'s the relevant code: The problem with this test is that DNS services providers such as level3 answer queries for non-existing hostnames with the IP of their search portal. Currently
column12: the machine that runs our Jenkin\'s SmartOS node is setup to use this DNS service
column13: and thus the test fails. It doesn\'t fail all the time because this node is also configured to use another DNS service that does not reply with redirects. If level3\'s DNS server is commented out from /
column14: the test works as expected. We could change the configuration of the Jenkin\'s SmartOS node
column15: but it will still fail if we move the Jenkins node to another machine with the same DNS config issues. It seems these days I want to solve every testing issue with
column16: but it could be a good solution to test DNS failures properly. We could override using to make sure the dns lookup fails when we invoke the test. This method doesn\'t work on Windows
column17: but we might be able to do something equivalent with SetWindowsHookEx. What do you think?"'

column10: b"b' Buffer re-use in streams'"
b'b" Hello
column11: currently at Volafile we\'re using some custom code to \'stream\' data to a http client that appears to outperform just using \'pipe\' by a factor of up to 5 (CPU time). I believe the main reason for this is that we are re-using the \'read\' buffer
column12: which can safely be doneafter \'write\' reported all data has been flushed to the underlying system. Actually we\'re using 2 buffers
column13: one that is currently being consumed by write
column14: and the second one to keep reading data in the meantime... but anyways. My proposal is to add a special option upon creation of a ReadStream that allows nodejs\'s internals to re-use the buffers it uses for reading data AFTER all destinations report that they\'ve completely consumed the data. This would be a feature that will not break any existing code as the user would have to explicitly state that he wished to use this feature (thereby saying \'Hey! I promise I will not use this buffer after I reportedly consumed it!\'). Here\'s the code we currently use @ Volafile:url It has some fancy features like rate limiting and automatically growing buffers which can be ignored for now. Also it uses my own [bastardized variant of JavaScript]url  which shouldn\'t be too much of a problem (It is almost vanilla JavaScript). **Edit**: I should also mention that on top of being much easier on the CPU
column15: it runs with a \'static\' amount of memory (except when growing buffers). Before you could see \' memory usage grow to something roughly equivalent to your file size (if the GC didn\'t kick in before the serving finished)
column16: now you barely can see anything at all. "'

column10: b'b" @laino as far as I can see
column11: your code only works for reading from file fd? if so
column12: you are actually optimizing  reading
column13: not piping. It\'s a good idea
column14: but you can\'t apply to
column15: because there is no way to know if it\'s safe to reuse emitted buffer."'

column10: b'b\' @vkurchatkin Exactly. Which is why a proposed the flag. The flag (option) would be provided by the user upon creation of the stream
column11: something along the lines of (file
column12: {reuseBuffers: true})
column13: then
column14: whenever a chunk emitted by the read stream has reportedly been consumed
column15: it would be reused to read more data into it. Anyways
column16: this was my initial proposal. In the meantime I came up with this: The ([chunk]
column17: [encoding]
column18: callback) method\\\'s callback could gain another argument
column19: so when you have consumed
column20: you can (optionally) pass it back to callback to allow it to be reused as a future buffer. like this: Note how I\\\'m passing the chunk back to the callback. The readable could then add it to some "reuse for future data" queue.\''

column10: b"b' http: fix >90% performance regression for GET requests using '"
b"b' ## Problem This is an attempt to fix issue #8940
column11: which describes a performance regression which started with commit 1fddc1f; more specifically
column12: the number of requests per second dropped from ~18k to ~1.1k (on my machine) in between v0.10.31 and v0.10.32. This can be tested easily as described in issue #8940:   The problem comes from commit 1fddc1f
column13: in particular from the following lines
column14: which are aimed at HEAD requests: However
column15: the instruction will never execute for HEAD requests
column16: since is always because of line [:1073]url  but it will execute for all GET requests since the conditions will match. Therefore
column17: hot-path optimization will never be done for GET requests when sending data via  .## Fix The fix is simply to remove the lines mentioned above: As previously explained
column18: this executes only for GET requests
column19: not for HEAD requests
column20: as it was intended. Simply removing them will allow GET requests to have the hot-path optimization when is not empty
column21: while HEAD requests will be non-optimized since there is no need (i.e no body).## Testing As far as I can tell
column22: there are three conditions which need to be met in order for the fix to be considered safe:1. Performance should be at pre-1fddc1f levels for the script in #8940.2. Pass all of the node tests
column23: which also includes the one which came packaged with 1fddc1f.3. As a bonus
column24: make sure that #8361 is still fixed. For no. 1
column25: I have tested that the performance is at pre-1fddc1 levels after deleting those three lines. For no. 2
column26: I have made sure that the Node tests  in the same way  the fix.  For no. 3
column27: I have tried those scripts
column28: everything is fine.  '"

b'b" I find it very confusing that [the code mentioned above]url  _silently_ swallows the property. It seems that the reason for having a property that overlaps and was to make writing easier. Maybe we could revisit [how it was implemented]url  and make the url module\'s API more robust or at least more explicit when it\'s not used as intended?"'
b"b' Reopening to continue the discussion.'"
b'b\' For my part
column11: I\\\'m okay with higher level keys overriding lower level keys (even silently)
column12: and -0 on making throw on duplicate keys. The confusion in these APIs stems from the fact that both functions interact with the same object
column13: but have different expectations of use: gives multiple levels of keys for informational purposes
column14: because it\\\'s often easier to deal with than +  . On the other hand
column15: (_correctly_
column16: I think) treats lower level keys as subordinate to higher level keys. Problems crop up when trying to take the output of the one
column17: _slightly_ modify it
column18: and pass it to the other. This has never worked well
column19: thanks to and
column20: and now works even less well thanks to  . Worse yet
column21: from a user perspective it seems _very_ easy to DWIM
column22: but from the format side it\\\'s ~~impossible~~ **difficult** to tell which properties were "affected" last. Some potential paths out of this:1. Make treat "own" properties higher in priority than inherited properties
column23: retaining all other key relationships. Make return an object inheriting from the parse object. User modifications now "win" vs. higher level keys from  .2. Add an option to that forces "lowest level of keys"-only output.3. Throw an exception on conflicting keys.4. Retain current behavior and document it heavily. 3 and 4 leave us (and users) in the same state \\xe2\\x80\\x93 leaning on documentation
column24: and without the ability to pass the output of to the input of  . Solutions 1 and 2 get us closer to that ability
column25: but have their own drawbacks: 1 seems _very_ convoluted (if it works
column26: it works well
column27: but if it doesn\\\'t do what\\\'s expected
column28: then it\\\'s hard to see _why_)
column29: and 2 is hard to discover.\''

column10: b'b" Definitely understand the logic but it\'s certainly non-obvious. At the very least
column11: this needs to be clearly described in the api docs."'

column10: b'b" 1 -doesn\'t solve the problem of user creating invalid input2 -an additional api tweaking here means that the default case will still be the predominate usage and we still don\'t know what that is yet3 -fits more in line with what I prefer
column11: but not just when conflicting keys appear but only when their contents cannot result in the same data.4 -I\'m not sure if documentation is enough
column12: as this can lead to very subtle bugs. In the event of throwing users at least have recourse to read the documentation
column13: with silent action things are happening and they may not be aware of it. I think this would be a good conversation to have during the call tomorrow morning."'

column10: b'b" There is perhaps a 5th option... it breaks api compatibility but perhaps that is ok: Have the result of parse() return an object that has it\'s own format() method
column11: the input of which allows a developer to pass in overriding values that are taken before the parse object\'s own.. e.g. Here the override would have to be explicit and the original parsed object remains untouched by the overrides. We can throw as suggested if the input to format contains conflicting values (e.g.  )"'

column10: b"b' Recording the results of the meeting: In the future we will throw on _all_ conflicting keys \\xe2\\x80\\x93 that is
column11: if and are both present
column12: but would produce different results
column13: we will throw an exception. This would extend to (+ / ) and (+ .) For the time being (v0.12)
column14: we will **only** present this behavior for the key
column15: which is a new key for  . I will be handling this change and its associated documentation.'"

column10: b'b" @chrisdickinson @tjfontaine Sorry to continue on a discussion after we agreed on a decision
column11: but I\'d like to express one concern that I didn\'t mention during the meeting. It seems to me that throwing in  happen much later after setting conflicting properties
column12: making tracking the cause of issues difficult
column13: and thus in my opinion defeating the purpose of throwing because the context would be lost."'

column12:
if and are both present, but would produce different results"... what\\\'s the plan on determining if they "produce different results". If is and is  , do you throw? \''

column10: b"b' 0.11.15 binary linked against GLIBCXX_3.4.15 breaks centos 6.5 default support'"
b'b" It said gcc 4.2 or above is enough to compile the source
column11: however the published binary linked against GLIBCXX_3.4.15 which is not included in gcc 4.4.7 shipped with Centos 6.5. (Might also breaks CentOS 6.6 as it\'s also shipped with gcc 4.4.7)Is it intended? Will this also be true in 0.12 binary?As CentOS 6.5 is still widely used in production environment
column12: this requires compiling & install newer gcc or node by hand
column13: which adds extra complexity in production environments. Is it possible to add some workaround about this?"'

column10: b'b\' Currently
column11: Linux binaries are built on CentOS 5.7 with gcc 4.7.3 and g++ 4.7.3
column12: and some code in V8 makes it require a libstdc++ that supports GLIBCXX_3.4.15: I don\\\'t think it is "intended"
column13: it\\\'s probably more that it fell through the cracks. However
column14: I was able to build node on the same build machine with gcc and g++ 4.4.7-1 [with a simple patch]url  All tests pass and the binary doesn\\\'t require a libstdc++ at version GLIBCXX_3.4.15 anymore. I think we should try to build node binaries with the oldest toolchain possible
column15: as long as it doesn\\\'t have a negative impact on the rest of the supported platforms. There are a lot of additional warnings triggered when using older C and C++ compilers though
column16: and I think we would need to fix these before if we were to go down that path. So my suggestion would be to:1) Submit a PR with a patch that makes node build with gcc and g++ 4.4.7 on CentOS with all tests passing and no additional warning (or as few as possible).2) If 1) is successful
column17: change the build jobs to use gcc and g++ 4.4.7 to build Linux binaries.3) Test that these binaries work as expected on a wide range of Linux platforms. I\\\'m not sure how that would fit in the current release schedule though
column18: as we\\\'re approaching the release of (hopefully) one of the latest release candidates for 0.12.0 and that could potentially break a lot of users on Linux.\''

column10: b"b' Reduced test case: Agreed it seems a little odd.'"
b"b' @erikcorry Is this expected?'"
b'b\' This is expected.  You are building a 100 million character string
column11: 1character at a time.  That builds a chain with 100m elements
column12: each being anobject of 32 or 40 bytes. Instead of using + on a string
column13: push the characters on an array
column14: then usejoin at the end. That will only use about a gigabyte. Or you can periodically flatten the string with (/./)
column15: but that willtake quadratic time for large strings.On 30 Jan 2015 00:29

column10: b'b\' I would argue that this is working as designed. runs in this _context_
column11: but that is akin to rather than  .  That is
column12: it runs in this global environment
column13: but _not_ inline in the same closure scope where it is invoked. is a function parameter (aka a "free var")
column14: not a global.  (Along with
column17: and  .)  This is designed in this way because each module has to have a different function in order to behave properly.  (Remember
column18: is relative to the _module_
column19: not the current working directory.) If there was an easy way to put closure scope free vars and declared vars
column20: then it would surely be a useful thing to have on the vm module.  But it would need to be a different name
column21: or else this would introduce a very subtle breaking change that is probably not worth the hazard. I recommend closing this issue if the TSC doesn\\\'t decide it\\\'s worth putting on the roadmap.\''

column10: b'b\' If there is a "bug" here
column11: imo
column12: it\\\'s that this _does_ work in and modes
column13: not that it _doesn\\\'t_ work in module mode.  And that bug is fixable
column14: we just have to wrap the code rather than making stuff global.\''

The two cases of would be to run in the current execution scope (which @n-riesco is basically what you\'re asking for). Or to run with the same of the caller. Neither are true. The only thing you are given is that inside the code. @domenic Is this how it\'s supposed to work?"'

column11: there are several header files that are packaged with Node which make native addon development possible.  Amongst them are headers for v8

column13: libuv
column14: etc.  I\'ve noticed that there\'s even an subdirectory that contains a single header file: . Well it turns out that OSX ships with OpenSSL 0.9.8 by default
column15: and when Node is compiled using its own bundled version of OpenSSL
column16: the verison is much more recent and includes some features that I\'d like to use
column17: specifically. So this feature request is relatively simple:  When Node is built using it\'s bundled version of OpenSSL (no  )
column18: can the headers for the included version be shipped in that subdirectory?"'

column10: b'b" A related issue is #5112 Keep in mind that in part because we don\'t have a well defined  it means that if you link against our compiled openssl you will be stuck using only the symbols we consume. So if there\'s a deficiency in our existing consumption of openssl
column11: it\'s likely that just linking against ours won\'t be sufficient. Some of this can be fixed with map files etc
column12: but we have to decide what we want our public symbols for node to be. Or you can ship your own copy of openssl with your module
column13: but you want to make sure it\'s scoped local to your binary addon such that our static openssl doesn\'t interfere with yours."'

column10: b'b" For me this is perfectly acceptable since I don\'t actually link statically to OpenSSL.  I always end up using whatever node bundles."'

column10: b'b" I have also been looking at the problem
column11: and I am able to reproduce on Windows and Linux. It does look like the issue is caused by writing to a socket that has been destroyed. Ideally
column12: I/O operations on sockets should be checking to see if they have been destroyed.  At the moment I\'m working on a simplified test case to reproduce the issue"'

column10: b"b' I think I have this tracked down and it has to do with the way file io is processed by the thread pool.  Basically
column11: when the write to the socket occurs
column12: it is still open (and thus the checks all pass). A request is then put in the queue to be processed by a worker in the thread pool. Before the request gets picked up
column13: the socket gets closed
column14: thus when the threadpool worker starts the request it segfaults.  Ideally
column15: should set the state to closed (to prevent further )
column16: and wait for outstanding requests to finish before actually closing the handle and settig it to null. Now its just a matter of figuring out how to make that happen'"

column10: b"b' This aught to fix the issue  eed93923ab'"

b"b' I was looking at this some more and my previous conclusion was wrong. In  the end the problem is that you are closing the underlying socket and the server tries to write to the TLS socket (which shares a handle
column11: but is not notified when the regular socket is destroyed). The solution is to listen for the event rather than the event'"

column10: b"b' @EricSmekens sounds like  you are getting that error because you are trying to bind to the server socket before it has been released. Looking at my code I added a delay
column11: so maybe I was hitting the same problem. Relevant code: Also note
column12: I moved before the for loop. This stops the server from accepting new connections while you are closing the old ones. '"

column10: b"b' Also
column11: for anybody thats interested
column12: the problem arises because while the TLS socket
column13: and the normal socket share the file handle
column14: they maintain little no level of coordination. My initial solution was to add a line to the TLSSocket constructor
column15: however this does not work due to some of the oddities of the handle
column16: namely the method of the underlying handle which has code equivalent to the following: Which means that a second call to  on  the same file handle does not behave as expected'"

column10: b"b' events: fix: shared object references'"
b"b' Fixes the issue: url  When emitting to multiple listeners for the same event type
column11: the forloop iteration over these listeners shares the same arguments. Thismeans (for objects)
column12: the copy is only shallow
column13: and changes made by onelistener are overwritten on the object for the next listener. For example
column14: if we pass an object with arrays: as below And the first listener sets the users array as null like so: The second event listener will ALWAYS show the array as null. This isbecause only a shallow copy of the arguments is made and not a deepcopy. This fixes that issue
column15: by enforcing a deep copy and removing allreferences from the new arguments array passed to each listener. Link to code used to reproduce this issue:url  Link to issue:url '"

Server should process all the requests successfully which are in flight and then restart the server. After doing some research i found () function which is said to be used in such cases. But I didn\'t see good results out of it. Sometimes it rejects the new incoming connections or sometimes it restarts the server before finishing the requests which are on the fly. I pass a signal to the process through command line which is handled in my server code.  Also as I use cluster

column10: b"b' Found the solution which is as follows: While closing server we had called () once. We changed it to run the foreach loop for the servers array created above and we called () inside the loop so that server running on each port gets closed individually which solved the problem.'"
